| where (eventType in ('HealthAdvisory', 'SecurityAdvisory', 'PlannedMaintenance') and impactMitigationTime > now()) or (eventType == 'ServiceIssue' and status == 'Active')

documentation.title: abs()
documentation.description: Calculates the absolute value of the input.
documentation.returnInfo: Absolute value of x.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *x* | int, real, or timespan |  *True* | The value to make absolute. |
documentation.example: print abs(-5)

documentation.title: acos()
documentation.description: Calculates the angle whose cosine is the specified number. Inverse operation of `cos()`.
documentation.returnInfo: The value of the arc cosine of `x`. The return value is `null` if `x` < -1 or `x` > 1.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *x* | `real` |  *True* | The value used to calculate the arc cosine. |

documentation.title: ago()
documentation.description:
Subtracts the given timespan from the current UTC time.

Like `now()`, if you use `ago()` multiple times in a single query statement, the current UTC time
being referenced is the same across all uses.
documentation.returnInfo: A datetime value equal to the current time minus the timespan.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:---|:---|:---|:---|
| *timespan* | `timespan` |  *True* | The interval to subtract from the current UTC clock time `now()`. For a full list of possible timespan values, see timespan literals.|
documentation.example: T | where Timestamp > ago(1h)

documentation.title: around()
documentation.description: Creates a `bool` value indicating if the first argument is within a range around the center value.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns `true` if the value is within the range, `false` if the value is outside the range.
Returns `null` if any of the arguments is `null`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*value*| int, long, real, datetime, or timespan |  *True* | The value to compare to the *center*.|
| *center* | int, long, real, datetime, or timespan |  *True* | The center of the range defined as [(`center`-`delta`) .. (`center` + `delta`)]. |
| *delta* | int, long, real, datetime, or timespan |  *True* | The delta value of the range defined as [(`center`-`delta`) .. (`center` + `delta`)].|
documentation.example:
range dt 
    from datetime(2021-01-01 01:00) 
    to datetime(2021-01-01 02:00) 
    step 1min
| where around(dt, datetime(2021-01-01 01:30), 1min)

documentation.title: array_concat()
documentation.description: Concatenates many dynamic arrays to a single array.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a dynamic array of all input arrays.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *arr* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The arrays to concatenate into a dynamic array.|
documentation.example:
range x from 1 to 3 step 1
| extend y = x * 2
| extend z = y * 2
| extend a1 = pack_array(x,y,z), a2 = pack_array(x, y)
| project array_concat(a1, a2)

documentation.title: array_iff()
documentation.description:
Element-wise `iif` function on dynamic arrays.

> The `array_iff()` and `array_iif()` functions are equivalent
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a dynamic array of the values taken either from the *when_true* or *when_false* array values, according to the corresponding value of the condition array.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *condition_array*| `dynamic` |  *True*| An array of *boolean* or numeric values.|
| *when_true* | dynamic or scalar |  *True* | An array of values or primitive value. It's the result when *condition_array* is *true*.|
| *when_false* | dynamic or scalar |  *True* | An array of values or primitive value. It's the result when *condition_array* is *false*.|

> [!NOTE]
>
> * The length of the return value is same as the input *condition_array*.
> * Numeric condition values are considered `true` if not equal to 0.
> * Non-numeric and non-boolean condition values is null in the corresponding index of the return value.
> * If *when_true* or *when_false* is shorter than *condition_array*, missing values are treated as null.
documentation.example:
print condition=dynamic([true,false,true]), if_true=dynamic([1,2,3]), if_false=dynamic([4,5,6]) 
| extend res= array_iff(condition, if_true, if_false)

print condition=dynamic([1,0,50]), if_true="yes", if_false="no" 
| extend res= array_iff(condition, if_true, if_false)

print condition=dynamic(["some string value", datetime("01-01-2022"), null]), if_true=1, if_false=0
| extend res= array_iff(condition, if_true, if_false)

print condition=dynamic([true,true,true]), if_true=dynamic([1,2]), if_false=dynamic([3,4]) 
| extend res= array_iff(condition, if_true, if_false)

documentation.title: array_index_of()
documentation.description: Searches an array for the specified item, and returns its position.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a zero-based index position of lookup.
Returns -1 if the value isn't found in the array.
Returns *null* for irrelevant inputs (*occurrence* < 0 or  *length* < -1).
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *array* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The array to search. |
| *value* | long, int, datetime, timespan, string, guid, or bool |  *True* | The value to lookup. |
| *start* | `int` |  | The search start position. A negative value will offset the starting search value from the end of the array by `abs(`*start*`)` steps. |
| *length* | `int` |  | The number of values to examine. A value of -1 means unlimited length. |
| *occurrence* | `int` |  | The number of the occurrence. The default is 1. |
documentation.example:
let arr=dynamic(["this", "is", "an", "example", "an", "example"]);
print
 idx1 = array_index_of(arr,"an")    // lookup found in input string
 , idx2 = array_index_of(arr,"example",1,3) // lookup found in researched range 
 , idx3 = array_index_of(arr,"example",1,2) // search starts from index 1, but stops after 2 values, so lookup can't be found
 , idx4 = array_index_of(arr,"is",2,4) // search starts after occurrence of lookup
 , idx5 = array_index_of(arr,"example",2,-1)  // lookup found
 , idx6 = array_index_of(arr, "an", 1, -1, 2)   // second occurrence found in input range
 , idx7 = array_index_of(arr, "an", 1, -1, 3)   // no third occurrence in input array
 , idx8 = array_index_of(arr, "an", -3)   // negative start index will look at last 3 elements
 , idx9 = array_index_of(arr, "is", -4)   // negative start index will look at last 3 elements

documentation.title: array_length()
documentation.description:
Calculates the number of elements in a dynamic array.

> **Deprecated aliases:** arraylength()
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the number of elements in *array*, or `null` if *array* isn't an array.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *array* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The array for which to calculate length.
documentation.example: print array_length(dynamic([1, 2, 3, "four"]))

documentation.title: array_reverse()
documentation.description: Reverses the order of the elements in a dynamic array.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns an array that contains the same elements as the input array in reverse order.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*value*| `dynamic` |  *True*| The array to reverse.|
documentation.example:
print arr=dynamic(["this", "is", "an", "example"]) 
| project Result=array_reverse(arr)

documentation.title: array_rotate_left()
documentation.description: Rotates values inside a `dynamic` array to the left.
documentation.returnInfo: Dynamic array containing the same elements as the original array with each element rotated according to *rotate_count*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*array* | `dynamic` |  *True*| The array to rotate.|
|*rotate_count*| integer |  *True*| The number of positions that array elements will be rotated to the left. If the value is negative, the elements will be rotated to the right.|
documentation.example:
print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5])
| extend arr_rotated=array_rotate_left(arr, 2)

print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5])
| extend arr_rotated=array_rotate_left(arr, -2)

documentation.title: array_rotate_right()
documentation.description: Rotates values inside a `dynamic` array to the right.
documentation.returnInfo: Dynamic array containing the same elements as the original array with each element rotated according to *rotate_count*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*array* | `dynamic` |  *True*| The array to rotate.|
|*rotate_count*| integer |  *True*| The number of positions that array elements will be rotated to the right. If the value is negative, the elements will be rotated to the Left.|
documentation.example:
print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5])
| extend arr_rotated=array_rotate_right(arr, 2)

print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5])
| extend arr_rotated=array_rotate_right(arr, -2)

documentation.title: array_shift_left()
documentation.description: Shifts the values inside a dynamic array to the left.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a dynamic array containing the same number of elements as in the original array. Each element has been shifted according to *shift_count*. New elements that are added in place of removed elements have a value of *default_value*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*array* | `dynamic` | *True* | The array to shift.|
|*shift_count* | `int` |  *True* | The number of positions that array elements are shifted to the left. If the value is negative, the elements are shifted to the right. |
|*default_value* | scalar | | The value used for an element that was shifted and removed. The default is null or an empty string depending on the type of elements in the *array*.|
documentation.example:
print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5])
| extend arr_shift=array_shift_left(arr, 2)

print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5])
| extend arr_shift=array_shift_left(arr, 2, -1)

print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5])
| extend arr_shift=array_shift_left(arr, -2, -1)

documentation.title: array_shift_right()
documentation.description: Shifts the values inside a dynamic array to the right.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a dynamic array containing the same amount of the elements as in the original array. Each element has been shifted according to *shift_count*. New elements that are added instead of the removed elements have a value of *default_value*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*array* | `dynamic` | *True* | The array to shift.|
|*shift_count* | `int` |  *True* | The number of positions that array elements are shifted to the right. If the value is negative, the elements are shifted to the left. |
|*default_value* | scalar | | The value used for an element that was shifted and removed. The default is null or an empty string depending on the type of elements in the *array*.|
documentation.example:
print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5])
| extend arr_shift=array_shift_right(arr, 2)

print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5])
| extend arr_shift=array_shift_right(arr, 2, -1)

print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5])
| extend arr_shift=array_shift_right(arr, -2, -1)

documentation.title: array_slice()
documentation.description: Extracts a slice of a dynamic array.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a dynamic array of the values in the range [`start..end`] from `array`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *array* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The array from which to extract the slice.|
| *start*| `int` |  *True* | The start index of the slice (inclusive). Negative values are converted to `array_length`+`start`.|
| *end*| `int` |  *True* | The last index of the slice. (inclusive). Negative values are converted to `array_length`+`end`.|

> [!NOTE]
> Out of bounds indices are ignored.
documentation.example:
print arr=dynamic([1,2,3]) 
| extend sliced=array_slice(arr, 1, 2)

print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5]) 
| extend sliced=array_slice(arr, 2, -1)

print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5]) 
| extend sliced=array_slice(arr, -3, -2)

documentation.title: array_sort_asc()
documentation.description: Receives one or more arrays. Sorts the first array in ascending order. Orders the remaining arrays to match the reordered first array.
documentation.syntax:
`array_sort_asc(`*array1*[, ..., *arrayN*][`,` *nulls_last*]`)`

If *nulls_last* isn't provided, a default value of `true` is used.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns the same number of arrays as in the input, with the first array sorted in ascending order, and the remaining arrays ordered to match the reordered first array.

`null` is returned for every array that differs in length from the first one.

An array which contains elements of different types, is sorted in the following order:

* Numeric, `datetime`, and `timespan` elements
* String elements
* Guid elements
* All other elements
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*array1...arrayN*| `dynamic` |  *True* | The array or list of arrays to sort.|
| *nulls_last* | `bool` |  | Determines whether `null`s should be last.|
documentation.example:
let array1 = dynamic([1,3,4,5,2]);
let array2 = dynamic(["a","b","c","d","e"]);
print array_sort_asc(array1,array2)

let Names = "John,Paul,Jane,Kao";
let SortedNames = strcat_array(array_sort_asc(split(Names, ",")), ",");
print result = SortedNames

datatable(command:string, command_time:datetime, user_id:string)
[
    'chmod',   datetime(2019-07-15),   "user1",
    'ls',      datetime(2019-07-02),   "user1",
    'dir',     datetime(2019-07-22),   "user1",
    'mkdir',   datetime(2019-07-14),   "user1",
    'rm',      datetime(2019-07-27),   "user1",
    'pwd',     datetime(2019-07-25),   "user1",
    'rm',      datetime(2019-07-23),   "user2",
    'pwd',     datetime(2019-07-25),   "user2",
]
| summarize timestamps = make_list(command_time), commands = make_list(command) by user_id
| project user_id, commands_in_chronological_order = array_sort_asc(timestamps, commands)[1]

print result=array_sort_asc(dynamic([null,"blue","yellow","green",null]))

print result=array_sort_asc(dynamic([null,"blue","yellow","green",null]), false)

documentation.title: array_sort_desc()
documentation.description: Receives one or more arrays. Sorts the first array in descending order. Orders the remaining arrays to match the reordered first array.
documentation.syntax:
`array_sort_desc(`*array1*[, ..., *argumentN*]`)`

`array_sort_desc(`*array1*[, ..., *argumentN*]`,`*nulls_last*`)`

If *nulls_last* isn't provided, a default value of `true` is used.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns the same number of arrays as in the input, with the first array sorted in ascending order, and the remaining arrays ordered to match the reordered first array.

`null` is returned for every array that differs in length from the first one.

An array which contains elements of different types, is sorted in the following order:

* Numeric, `datetime`, and `timespan` elements
* String elements
* Guid elements
* All other elements
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*array1...arrayN*| `dynamic` |  *True* | The array or list of arrays to sort.|
| *nulls_last* | `bool` |  | Determines whether `null`s should be last.|
documentation.example:
let array1 = dynamic([1,3,4,5,2]);
let array2 = dynamic(["a","b","c","d","e"]);
print array_sort_desc(array1,array2)

let Names = "John,Paul,Jane,Kayo";
let SortedNames = strcat_array(array_sort_desc(split(Names, ",")), ",");
print result = SortedNames

datatable(command:string, command_time:datetime, user_id:string)
[
    'chmod',   datetime(2019-07-15),   "user1",
    'ls',      datetime(2019-07-02),   "user1",
    'dir',     datetime(2019-07-22),   "user1",
    'mkdir',   datetime(2019-07-14),   "user1",
    'rm',      datetime(2019-07-27),   "user1",
    'pwd',     datetime(2019-07-25),   "user1",
    'rm',      datetime(2019-07-23),   "user2",
    'pwd',     datetime(2019-07-25),   "user2",
]
| summarize timestamps = make_list(command_time), commands = make_list(command) by user_id
| project user_id, commands_in_chronological_order = array_sort_desc(timestamps, commands)[1]

print result=array_sort_desc(dynamic([null,"blue","yellow","green",null]))

print result=array_sort_desc(dynamic([null,"blue","yellow","green",null]), false)

documentation.title: array_split()
documentation.description: Splits an array to multiple arrays according to the split indices and packs the generated array in a dynamic array.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a dynamic array containing N+1 arrays with the values in the range `[0..i1), [i1..i2), ... [iN..array_length)` from `array`, where N is the number of input indices and `i1...iN` are the indices.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *array*| `dynamic` |  *True* | The array to split.|
| *index* | `int` or `dynamic` |  *True*| An integer or dynamic array of integers used to indicate the location at which to split the array. The start index of arrays is zero. Negative values are converted to `array_length` + `value`.|
documentation.example:
print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5]) 
| extend arr_split=array_split(arr, 2)

print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4,5]) 
| extend arr_split=array_split(arr, dynamic([1,3]))

documentation.title: array_sum()
documentation.description: Calculates the sum of elements in a dynamic array.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a double type value with the sum of the elements of the array.

> [!NOTE]
> If the array contains elements of non-numeric types, the result is `null`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *array*| `dynamic` |  *True*| The array to sum.|
documentation.example:
print arr=dynamic([1,2,3,4]) 
| extend arr_sum=array_sum(arr)

documentation.title: asin()
documentation.description: Calculates the angle whose sine is the specified number, or the arc sine. This is the inverse operation of `sin()`.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the value of the arc sine of `x`. Returns `null` if `x` < -1 or `x` > 1.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*x* | `real` |  *True*| A real number in range [-1, 1] used to calculate the arc sine.|
documentation.example: asin(0.5)

documentation.title: assert()
documentation.description:
Checks for a condition. If the condition is false, outputs error messages and fails the query.

> [!NOTE]
> The `assert` function gets evaluated during the query analysis phase, before optimizations such as constant-folding and predicate short-circuiting get applied.

> [!NOTE]
> The parameters given to `assert` must be evaluated to constants during the query analysis phase. In other words, it can be constructed from other expressions referencing constants only, and can't be bound to row-context.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns `true` if the condition is `true`.
Raises a semantic error if the condition is evaluated to `false`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *condition* | `bool` |  *True* | The conditional expression to evaluate. The condition must be evaluated to constant during the query analysis phase.|
| *message* | `string` |  *True* | The message used if assertion is evaluated to `false`.|

documentation.title: atan()
documentation.description: Returns the angle whose tangent is the specified number. This is the inverse operation of `tan()`.
documentation.returnInfo: The value of the arc tangent of `x`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *x* | `real` |  *True* | The number used to calculate the arc tangent.|
documentation.example: atan(0.5)

documentation.title: atan2()
documentation.description: Calculates the angle, in radians, between the positive x-axis and the ray from the origin to the point (y, x).
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the angle in radians between the positive x-axis and the ray from the origin to the point (y, x).
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *y* | `real` |  *True* | The Y coordinate.|
| *x* | `real` |  *True* | The X coordinate.|
documentation.example:
print atan2_0 = atan2(1,1) // Pi / 4 radians (45 degrees)
| extend atan2_1 = atan2(0,-1) // Pi radians (180 degrees)
| extend atan2_2 = atan2(-1,0) // - Pi / 2 radians (-90 degrees)

documentation.title: bag_has_key()
documentation.description: Checks whether a dynamic property bag object contains a given key.
documentation.returnInfo: True or false depending on if the key exists in the bag.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
| *bag* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The property bag to search. |
| *key* | `string` |  *True* | The key for which to search.  Search for a nested key using the JSONPath notation. Array indexing isn't supported. |
documentation.example:
datatable(input: dynamic)
[
    dynamic({'key1' : 123, 'key2': 'abc'}),
    dynamic({'key1' : 123, 'key3': 'abc'}),
]
| extend result = bag_has_key(input, 'key2')

datatable(input: dynamic)
[
    dynamic({'key1': 123, 'key2': {'prop1' : 'abc', 'prop2': 'xyz'}, 'key3': [100, 200]}),
]
| extend result = bag_has_key(input, '$.key2.prop1')

documentation.title: bag_keys()
documentation.description: Enumerates all the root keys in a dynamic property bag object.
documentation.returnInfo: An array of keys, order is undetermined.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
| *object* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The property bag object for which to enumerate keys. |
documentation.example:
datatable(index:long, d:dynamic) [
    1, dynamic({'a':'b', 'c':123}), 
    2, dynamic({'a':'b', 'c':{'d':123}}),
    3, dynamic({'a':'b', 'c':[{'d':123}]}),
    4, dynamic(null),
    5, dynamic({}),
    6, dynamic('a'),
    7, dynamic([])
]
| extend keys = bag_keys(d)

documentation.title: bag_merge()
documentation.description: The function merges multiple `dynamic` property bags into a single `dynamic` property bag object, consolidating all properties from the input bags.
documentation.returnInfo: A `dynamic` property bag containing the merged results of all input property bags. If a key is present in multiple input bags, the value associated with the key from the leftmost argument takes precedence.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
| *bag1...bagN* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The property bags to merge. The function accepts between 2 to 64 arguments. |
documentation.example:
print result = bag_merge(
   dynamic({'A1':12, 'B1':2, 'C1':3}),
   dynamic({'A2':81, 'B2':82, 'A1':1}))

documentation.title: bag_pack_columns()
documentation.description: Creates a dynamic property bag object from a list of columns.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a `dynamic` property bag object from the listed *columns*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*column*| scalar |  *True* | A column to pack. The name of the column is the property name in the property bag.|
documentation.example:
datatable(Id: string, Value: string, Other: long)
[
    "A", "val_a", 1,
    "B", "val_b", 2,
    "C", "val_c", 3
]
| extend Packed = bag_pack_columns(Id, Value)

documentation.title: bag_remove_keys()
documentation.description: Removes keys and associated values from a `dynamic` property bag.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a `dynamic` property bag without specified keys and their values.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
| *bag* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The property bag from which to remove keys. |
| *keys* | `dynamic` |  *True* | List of keys to be removed from the input. The keys are the first level of the property bag. You can specify keys on the nested levels using JSONPath notation. Array indexing isn't supported. |
documentation.example:
datatable(input:dynamic)
[
    dynamic({'key1' : 123,     'key2': 'abc'}),
    dynamic({'key1' : 'value', 'key3': 42.0}),
]
| extend result=bag_remove_keys(input, dynamic(['key2', 'key4']))

datatable(input:dynamic)
[
    dynamic({'key1': 123, 'key2': {'prop1' : 'abc', 'prop2': 'xyz'}, 'key3': [100, 200]}),
]
| extend result=bag_remove_keys(input, dynamic(['$.key2.prop1', 'key3']))

documentation.title: bag_set_key()
documentation.description: bag_set_key() receives a `dynamic` property-bag, a key and a value. The function sets the given key in the bag to the given value. The function overrides any existing value in case the key already exists.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a `dynamic` property-bag with specified key-value pairs. If the input bag isn't a property-bag, a `null` value is returned.

> [!NOTE]
> To treat `null`s as empty bags, use `coalesce(x, dynamic({}))`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *bag* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The property bag to modify. |
| *key* | `string` |  *True* | The key to set. Either a JSON path (you can specify a key on the nested levels using JSONPath notation) or the key name for a root level key. Array indexing or root JSON paths aren't supported. |
| *value* | any scalar data type |  *True* | The value to which the key is set. |
documentation.example:
datatable(input: dynamic) [
    dynamic({'key1': 1, 'key2': 2}), 
    dynamic({'key1': 1, 'key3': 'abc'}),
]
| extend result = bag_set_key(input, 'key3', 3)

datatable(input: dynamic)[
    dynamic({'key1': 123, 'key2': {'prop1': 123, 'prop2': 'xyz'}}),
    dynamic({'key1': 123})
]
| extend result = bag_set_key(input, '$.key2.prop1', 'abc')

documentation.title: base64_decode_toarray()
documentation.description: Decodes a base64 string to an array of long values.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns an array of long values decoded from a base64 string.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
| -- | -- | -- | -- |
| *base64_string* | `string` |  *True* |  The value to decode from base64 to an array of long values.|
documentation.example:
print Quine=base64_decode_toarray("S3VzdG8=")  
// 'K', 'u', 's', 't', 'o'

documentation.title: base64_decode_toguid()
documentation.description: Decodes a base64 string to a GUID.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a GUID decoded from a base64 string.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *base64_string* | `string` |  *True* | The value to decode from base64 to a GUID. |
documentation.example:
print Quine = base64_decode_toguid("JpbpECu8dUy7Pv5gbeJXAA==")  

print Empty = base64_decode_toguid("abcd1231")

documentation.title: base64_decode_tostring()
documentation.description:
Decodes a base64 string to a UTF-8 string.

> **Deprecated aliases:** base64_decodestring()
documentation.returnInfo: Returns UTF-8 string decoded from base64 string.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *base64_string* | `string` |  *True* | The value to decode from base64 to UTF-8 string. |
documentation.example:
print Quine=base64_decode_tostring("S3VzdG8=")

print Empty=base64_decode_tostring("U3RyaW5n0KHR0tGA0L7Rh9C60LA=")

documentation.title: base64_encode_fromarray()
documentation.description: Encodes a base64 string from a bytes array.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the base64 string encoded from the bytes array. Note that byte is an integer type.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *base64_string_decoded_as_a_byte_array* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The bytes (integer) array to be encoded into a base64 string. |

documentation.title: base64_encode_fromguid()
documentation.description: Encodes a GUID to a base64 string.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a base64 string encoded from a GUID.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *guid* | `guid` |  *True* | The value to encode to a base64 string. |
documentation.example:
print Quine = base64_encode_fromguid(toguid("ae3133f2-6e22-49ae-b06a-16e6a9b212eb"))  

print Empty = base64_encode_fromguid("abcd1231")

documentation.title: base64_encode_tostring()
documentation.description:
Encodes a string as base64 string.

> **Deprecated aliases:** base64_encodestring()
documentation.returnInfo: Returns *string* encoded as a base64 string.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *string* | `string` |  *True* |  The value to encode as a base64 string. |
documentation.example: print Quine=base64_encode_tostring("Kusto")

documentation.title: beta_cdf()
documentation.description:
Returns the standard cumulative beta distribution function.

If *probability* = `beta_cdf(`*x*,...`)`, then `beta_inv(`*probability*,...`)` = *x*.

The beta distribution is commonly used to study variation in the percentage of something across samples, such as the fraction of the day people spend watching television.
documentation.returnInfo:
The cumulative beta distribution function.

> [!NOTE]
>
> * If any argument is nonnumeric, the function returns `null`.
> * If `x < 0` or `x > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.
> * If `alpha  0` or `alpha > 10000`, the function returns `NaN`.
> * If `beta  0` or `beta > 10000`, the function returns `NaN`.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *x* | int, long, or real |  *True*| A value at which to evaluate the function.|
| *alpha* | int, long, or real |  *True*| A parameter of the distribution.|
| *beta* | int, long, or real |  *True*| A parameter of the distribution.|
documentation.example:
datatable(x:double, alpha:double, beta:double, comment:string)
[
    0.9, 10.0, 20.0, "Valid input",
    1.5, 10.0, 20.0, "x > 1, yields NaN",
    double(-10), 10.0, 20.0, "x < 0, yields NaN",
    0.1, double(-1.0), 20.0, "alpha is < 0, yields NaN"
]
| extend b = beta_cdf(x, alpha, beta)

documentation.title: beta_inv()
documentation.description:
Returns the inverse of the beta cumulative probability density function.

If *probability* = `beta_cdf(`*x*,...`)`, then `beta_inv(`*probability*,...`)` = *x*.

The beta distribution can be used in project planning to model probable completion times given an expected completion time and variability.
documentation.returnInfo:
The inverse of the beta cumulative probability density function beta_cdf()

> [!NOTE]
>
> * If any argument is nonnumeric, the function returns `null`.
> * If `alpha  0` or `beta  0`, the function returns `null`.
> * If `probability  0` or `probability > 1`, the function returns `NaN`.
> * Given a value for *probability*, `beta_inv()` seeks that value x such that `beta_cdf(x, alpha, beta)` `=` *probability*.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *probability* | int, long, or real |  *True*| A probability associated with the beta distribution.|
| *alpha* | int, long, or real |  *True*| A parameter of the distribution.|
| *beta* | int, long, or real |  *True*| A parameter of the distribution.|
documentation.example:
datatable(p:double, alpha:double, beta:double, comment:string)
[
    0.1, 10.0, 20.0, "Valid input",
    1.5, 10.0, 20.0, "p > 1, yields null",
    0.1, double(-1.0), 20.0, "alpha is < 0, yields NaN"
]
| extend b = beta_inv(p, alpha, beta)

documentation.title: beta_pdf()
documentation.description:
Returns the probability density beta function.

The beta distribution is commonly used to study variation in the percentage of something across samples, such as the fraction of the day people spend watching television.
documentation.returnInfo:
The probability beta density function.

> [!NOTE]
>
> * If any argument is nonnumeric, the function returns `null`.
> * If `x  0` or `1  x`, the function returns `NaN`.
> * If `alpha  0` or `beta  0`, the function returns `NaN`.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *x* | int, long, or real |  *True*| A value at which to evaluate the function.|
| *alpha* | int, long, or real |  *True*| A parameter of the distribution.|
| *beta* | int, long, or real |  *True*| A parameter of the distribution.|
documentation.example:
datatable(x:double, alpha:double, beta:double, comment:string)
[
    0.5, 10.0, 20.0, "Valid input",
    1.5, 10.0, 20.0, "x > 1, yields NaN",
    double(-10), 10.0, 20.0, "x < 0, yields NaN",
    0.1, double(-1.0), 20.0, "alpha is < 0, yields NaN"
]
| extend r = beta_pdf(x, alpha, beta)

documentation.title: bin()
documentation.description:
Rounds values down to an integer multiple of a given bin size.

Used frequently in combination with `summarize by ...`.
If you have a scattered set of values, they'll be grouped into a smaller set of specific values.

> The `bin()` and `floor()` functions are equivalent
documentation.returnInfo: The nearest multiple of *roundTo* below *value*. Null values, a null bin size, or a negative bin size will result in null.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* |  int, long, real, timespan, or datetime |  *True* | The value to round down. |
| *roundTo* |  int, long, real, or timespan |  *True* | The "bin size" that divides *value*. |
documentation.example:
print bin(4.5, 1)

print bin(time(16d), 7d)

print bin(datetime(1970-05-11 13:45:07), 1d)

let Start = datetime('2007-04-07');
let End = Start + 7d;
StormEvents
| where StartTime between (Start .. End)
| where State == "CALIFORNIA" and EventType == "Strong Wind"
| summarize PropertyDamage=sum(DamageProperty) by bin(StartTime, 1d)

let Start = datetime('2007-04-07');
let End = Start + 7d;
StormEvents
| where StartTime between (Start .. End)
| where State == "CALIFORNIA" and EventType == "Strong Wind"
| union (
    range x from 1 to 1 step 1
    | mv-expand StartTime=range(Start, End, 1d) to typeof(datetime)
    | extend PropertyDamage=0
    )
| summarize PropertyDamage=sum(DamageProperty) by bin(StartTime, 1d)

documentation.title: bin_at()
documentation.description:
Returns the value rounded down to the nearest bin size, which is aligned to a fixed reference point.

In contrast to the bin() function, where the point of alignment is predefined, bin_at() allows you to define a fixed point for alignment. Results can align before or after the fixed point.
documentation.returnInfo: The nearest multiple of *bin_size* below the given *value* that aligns to the specified *fixed_point*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | `int`, `long`, `real`, `timespan`, or `datetime` |  *True* | The value to round. |
| *bin_size* | `int`, `long`, `real`, or `timespan` |  *True* | The size of each bin. |
| *fixed_point* | `int`, `long`, `real`, `timespan`, or `datetime` |  *True* | A constant of the same type as *value*, which is used as a fixed reference point.|

> [!NOTE]
> If *value* is a `timespan` or `datetime`, then the *bin_size* must be a `timespan`.
documentation.example:
print bin_at(6.5, 2.5, 7)

print bin_at(time(1h), 1d, 12h)

print bin_at(datetime(2017-05-15 10:20:00.0), 1d, datetime(1970-01-01 12:00:00.0))

print bin_at(datetime(2017-05-17 10:20:00.0), 7d, datetime(2017-06-04 00:00:00.0))

datatable(Date:datetime, NumOfEvents:int)[
datetime(2018-02-24T15:14),3,
datetime(2018-02-24T15:24),4,
datetime(2018-02-23T16:14),4,
datetime(2018-02-23T17:29),4,
datetime(2018-02-26T15:14),5]
| summarize TotalEvents=sum(NumOfEvents) by bin_at(Date, 1d, datetime(2018-02-24 15:14:00.0000000))

documentation.title: bin_auto()
documentation.description: Rounds values down to a fixed-size bin, with control over the bin size and starting point provided by a query property.
documentation.returnInfo:
The nearest multiple of `query_bin_auto_size` below *value*, shifted so that `query_bin_auto_at`
will be translated into itself.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | int, long, real, timespan, or datetime |  *True* |  The value to round into bins. |

To control the bin size and starting point, set the following parameters before using the function.

| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *query_bin_auto_size* | int, long, real, or timespan |  *True* |  Indicates the size of each bin.|
| *query_bin_auto_at* | int, long, real, or timespan | |  Indicates one value of *value* which is a "fixed point" for which `bin_auto(fixed_point)` == `fixed_point`. Default is 0.|

documentation.title: binary_and()
documentation.description: Performs a bitwise `AND` operation on two values.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the result of a bitwise `AND` operation between `value1` and `value2`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value1* | `long` |  *True* | The left-hand value of the bitwise `AND` operation. |
| *value2* | `long` |  *True* | The right-hand value of the bitwise `AND` operation. |
documentation.example: print result = binary_and(6, 3)

documentation.title: binary_not()
documentation.description: Performs a bitwise negation operation on a given value.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns logical NOT operation on a number: value.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | `long` |  *True* | The value to negate. |
documentation.example: binary_not(100)

documentation.title: binary_or()
documentation.description: Performs a bitwise `or` operation on two values.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns logical OR operation on a pair of numbers: value1 | value2.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value1* | `long` |  *True* | The left-hand value of the bitwise `OR` operation. |
| *value2* | `long` |  *True* | The right-hand value of the bitwise `OR` operation. |
documentation.example: print result = binary_or(5, 3)

documentation.title: binary_shift_left()
documentation.description: Performs a binary shift left operation on a pair of numbers.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns binary shift left operation on a pair of numbers: value << (shift%64).
If n is negative, a NULL value is returned.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | `int` |  *True* | The value to shift left. |
| *shift* | `int` |  *True* | The number of bits to shift left. |
documentation.example: binary_shift_left(1,2)

documentation.title: binary_shift_right()
documentation.description: Performs a binary shift right operation on a pair of numbers.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns binary shift right operation on a pair of numbers: value >> (shift%64).
If n is negative, a NULL value is returned.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | `int` |  *True* | The value to shift right. |
| *shift* | `int` |  *True* | The number of bits to shift right. |
documentation.example: binary_shift_right(1,2)

documentation.title: binary_xor()
documentation.description: Performs a bitwise `xor` operation on two values.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns logical XOR operation on a pair of numbers: value1 ^ value2.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value1* | `int` |  *True* | The left-side value of the XOR operation. |
| *value2* | `int` |  *True* | The right-side value of the XOR operation. |
documentation.example:
binary_xor(1,1)

binary_xor(1,2)

documentation.title: bitset_count_ones()
documentation.description: Performs a bitwise operation on the binary representation of a number.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the number of set bits in the binary representation of a number.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *value* | `int` |  *True* | The value for which to calculate the number of set bits. |
documentation.example:
// 42 = 32+8+2 : b'00101010' == 3 bits set
print ones = bitset_count_ones(42)

documentation.title: case()
documentation.description:
Evaluates a list of predicates and returns the first result expression whose predicate is satisfied.

If none of the predicates return `true`, the result of the `else` expression is returned.
All `predicate` arguments must be expressions that evaluate to a  `boolean` value.
All `then` arguments and the `else` argument must be of the same type.
documentation.returnInfo: The value of the first *then_i* whose *predicate_i* evaluates to `true`, or the value of *else* if neither of the predicates are satisfied.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *predicate* | `string` |  *True* | An expression that evaluates to a `boolean` value. |
| *then* | `string` |  *True* | An expression that gets evaluated and its value is returned from the function if *predicate* is the first predicate that evaluates to `true`. |
| *else* | `string` |  *True* | An expression that gets evaluated and its value is returned from the function if neither of the *predicate_i* evaluate to `true`. |
documentation.example:
range Size from 1 to 15 step 2
| extend bucket = case(Size <= 3, "Small", 
                       Size <= 10, "Medium", 
                       "Large")

documentation.title: ceiling()
documentation.description: Calculates the smallest integer greater than, or equal to, the specified numeric expression.
documentation.returnInfo: The smallest integer greater than, or equal to, the specified numeric expression.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *number* | int, long, or real |  *True* | The value to round up. |
documentation.example: print c1 = ceiling(-1.1), c2 = ceiling(0), c3 = ceiling(0.9)

documentation.title: cluster()
documentation.description:
:::moniker range="azure-data-explorer"
Changes the reference of the query to a remote cluster. To access a database within the same cluster, use the database() function. For more information, see cross-database and cross-cluster queries.
:::moniker-end

:::moniker range="microsoft-fabric"
Changes the reference of the query to a remote Eventhouse. To access a database within the same Eventhouse, use the database() function. For more information, see cross-database and cross-cluster queries.
<!-- Update link to the correct version for Fabric -->
:::moniker-end
documentation.parametersTable:
:::moniker range="azure-data-explorer"
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *name* | `string` |  *True* | The name of the cluster to reference. The value can be specified as a fully qualified domain name, or the name of the cluster without the `.kusto.windows.net` suffix. The cluster name is treated as case-insenstive and the recommendation is to provide it lower-case. The value can't be the result of subquery evaluation. |
:::moniker-end

:::moniker range="microsoft-fabric"
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *name* | `string` |  *True* | The full URL of the Eventhouse to reference. The value can be specified as a fully qualified domain name, or the name of the Eventhouse. The Eventhouse name is treated as case-insenstive and the recommendation is to provide it lower-case. The value can't be the result of subquery evaluation. |
:::moniker-end

documentation.title: coalesce()
documentation.description: Evaluates a list of expressions and returns the first non-null (or non-empty for string) expression.
documentation.returnInfo: The value of the first *arg* whose value isn't null (or not-empty for string expressions).
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| arg | scalar |  *True* | The expression to be evaluated.|

> [!NOTE]
>
> * All arguments must be of the same type.
> * Maximum of 64 arguments is supported.
documentation.example: print result=coalesce(tolong("not a number"), tolong("42"), 33)

documentation.title: column_ifexists()
documentation.description:
Displays the column, if the column exists. Otherwise, it returns the default column.

> **Deprecated aliases:** columnifexists()
documentation.returnInfo: If *columnName* exists, then returns the column. Otherwise, it returns the *defaultValue* column.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *columnName* | `string` |  *True* | The name of the column to return.|
| *defaultValue* | scalar |  *True* | The default column to return if *columnName* doesn't exist in the table. This value can be any scalar expression. For example, a reference to another column.|
documentation.example: StormEvents | project column_ifexists("Capital", State)

documentation.title: column_names_of()
documentation.description: Returns the column names of a tabular expression.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a dynamic array of strings, where each element represents a column name of the `expression` schema. If the expression doesn't exist, an error is raised.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expression* | `expression` | *True* | The tabular expression to evaluate. |
