documentation.title: current_cluster_endpoint()
documentation.description:
:::moniker range="azure-data-explorer || azure-monitor || microsoft-sentinel"
Provides the network endpoint (DNS name) of the current cluster being queried.
::: moniker-end

:::moniker range="microsoft-fabric"
Provides the network endpoint (DNS name) of the current Eventhouse being queried.
::: moniker-end
documentation.returnInfo:
:::moniker range="azure-data-explorer || azure-monitor || microsoft-sentinel"
Returns the network endpoint (DNS name) of the current cluster being queried, as a value of type `string`.
::: moniker-end

:::moniker range="microsoft-fabric"
Returns the network endpoint (DNS name) of the current Eventhouse being queried, as a value of type `string`.
::: moniker-end
documentation.example: print strcat("This query executed on: ", current_cluster_endpoint())

documentation.title: current_database()
documentation.description:
PRovides the name of the database in scope (database that all query
entities are resolved against if no other database is specified).
documentation.returnInfo: Returns name of the database in scope as a value of type `string`.
documentation.example: print strcat("Database in scope: ", current_database())

documentation.title: current_principal()
documentation.description: Provides the current principal name that runs the query.
documentation.returnInfo:
The current principal fully qualified name (FQN) as a `string`.  
The string format is:  
*PrinciplaType*`=`*PrincipalId*`;`*TenantId*
documentation.example: print fqn=current_principal()

documentation.title: current_principal_details()
documentation.description: Provides details of the principal running the query.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns the details of the current principal as a dynamic. The following table describes the returned fields.

|Field|Description|
|:--|:--|
|UserPrincipalName|The sign-in identifier for users. For more information, see UPN.|
|IdentityProvider|The source that validates the identity of the principal.|
|Authority|The Microsoft Entra tenant ID.|
|Mfa|Indicates the use of multifactor authentication. For more information, see Access token claims reference.|
|Type|The category of the principal: `aaduser`, `aadapp`, or `aadgroup`.|
|DisplayName|The user-friendly name  for the principal that is displayed in the UI.|
|ObjectId|The Microsoft Entra object ID for the principal.|
|FQN|The Fully Qualified Name (FQN) of the principal. Valuable for security role management commands. For more information, see Referencing security principals.|
|Country|The user's country or region. This property is returned if the information is present. The value is a standard two-letter country or region code, for example, FR, JP, and SZ.|
|TenantCountry|The resource tenant's country or region, set at a tenant level by an admin. This property is returned if the information is present. The value is a standard two-letter country or region code, for example, FR, JP, and SZ. |
|TenantRegion|The region of the resource tenant. This property is returned if the information is present. The value is a standard two-letter country or region code, for example, FR, JP, and SZ. |
documentation.example: print details=current_principal_details()

documentation.title: current_principal_is_member_of()
documentation.description: Checks group membership or principal identity of the current principal running the query.
documentation.returnInfo: The function returns `true` if the current principal running the query is successfully matched for at least one input argument. If not, the function returns `false`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *group* | `dynamic` |  *True* | An array of string literals in which each literal represents a Microsoft Entra principal. See examples for Microsoft Entra principals.|

> [!NOTE]
>
> - To avoid throttling from Microsoft Entra ID, the `current_principal_is_member_of()` function only works with string literals. Using values that aren't string literals will result in an error in order to avoid a potentially large number of queries to Microsoft Entra ID.
> - 
> - For more information on Group Membership cache behavior, see Access control overview.
documentation.example:
print result=current_principal_is_member_of(
    'aaduser=user1@fabrikam.com', 
    'aadgroup=group1@fabrikam.com',
    'aadapp=66ad1332-3a94-4a69-9fa2-17732f093664;72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47'
    )

print result=current_principal_is_member_of(
    dynamic([
    'aaduser=user1@fabrikam.com', 
    'aadgroup=group1@fabrikam.com',
    'aadapp=66ad1332-3a94-4a69-9fa2-17732f093664;72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47'
    ]))

documentation.title: cursor_after()
documentation.description:
A predicate runs over the records of a table to compare their ingestion time against a database cursor.

> [!NOTE]
> This function can only be invoked on records of a table that has the
IngestionTime policy enabled.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a scalar value of type `bool` that indicates whether the record was ingested
after the database cursor *RHS* (`true`) or not (`false`).
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *RHS* | `string` |  *True* | Either an empty string literal or a valid database cursor value.|
documentation.example:
MyTable
| where cursor_after('2024-08-01T00:00:00Z')

documentation.title: cursor_before_or_at()
documentation.description:
A predicate function runs over the records of a table to compare their ingestion time against the database cursor time.

> [!NOTE]
> This function can only be invoked on records of a table that has the
IngestionTime policy enabled.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a scalar value of type `bool` that indicates whether the record was ingested
before or at the database cursor *RHS* (`true`) or not (`false`).
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *RHS* | `string` |  *True* | Either an empty string literal or a valid database cursor value.|
documentation.example:
MyTable
| where cursor_before_or_at('2024-08-01T12:00:00Z')

documentation.title: database()
documentation.description:
:::moniker range="azure-data-explorer"
Changes the reference of the query to a specific database within the cluster scope.

> [!NOTE]
>
> * For more information, see cross-database and cross-cluster queries.
> * For accessing remote cluster and remote database, see `cluster()` scope function.
:::moniker-end

:::moniker range="microsoft-fabric"
Changes the reference of the query to a specific database within the Eventhouse scope.
<!-- add link in the note to the Cross-database and cross-Eventhouse doc once it is created -->
> [!NOTE]
>
> * For accessing remote cluster and remote database, see `cluster()` scope function.
:::moniker-end
``
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *databaseName* | `string` | The name of the database to reference. The *databaseName* can be either the `DatabaseName` or `PrettyName`. The argument must be a constant value and can't come from a subquery evaluation.|

documentation.title: datetime_add()
documentation.description: Calculates a new datetime from a specified period multiplied by a specified amount, added to, or subtracted from a specified datetime.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a datetime after a certain time/date interval has been added.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *period* | `string` |  *True* | The length of time by which to increment.|
| *amount* | `int` |  *True* | The number of *periods* to add to or subtract from *datetime*. |
| *datetime* | `datetime` |  *True* | The date to increment by the result of the *period* x *amount* calculation. |

Possible values of *period*:

* Year
* Quarter
* Month
* Week
* Day
* Hour
* Minute
* Second
* Millisecond
* Microsecond
* Nanosecond
documentation.example:
print  year = datetime_add('year',1,make_datetime(2017,1,1)),
quarter = datetime_add('quarter',1,make_datetime(2017,1,1)),
month = datetime_add('month',1,make_datetime(2017,1,1)),
week = datetime_add('week',1,make_datetime(2017,1,1)),
day = datetime_add('day',1,make_datetime(2017,1,1)),
hour = datetime_add('hour',1,make_datetime(2017,1,1)),
minute = datetime_add('minute',1,make_datetime(2017,1,1)),
second = datetime_add('second',1,make_datetime(2017,1,1))

print  year = datetime_add('year',-5,make_datetime(2017,1,1)),
quarter = datetime_add('quarter',12,make_datetime(2017,1,1)),
month = datetime_add('month',-15,make_datetime(2017,1,1)),
week = datetime_add('week',100,make_datetime(2017,1,1))

documentation.title: datetime_diff()
documentation.description: Calculates the number of the specified periods between two datetime values.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns an integer that represents the amount of *periods* in the result of subtraction (*datetime1* - *datetime2*).
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *period* | `string` |  *True* | The measurement of time used to calculate the return value. See possible values.|
| *datetime1* | `datetime` |  *True* | The left-hand side of the subtraction equation.|
| *datetime2* | `datetime` |  *True* | The right-hand side of the subtraction equation. |

### Possible values of *period*

These values are case insensitive:

* Year
* Quarter
* Month
* Week
* Day
* Hour
* Minute
* Second
* Millisecond
* Microsecond
* Nanosecond
documentation.example:
print
year = datetime_diff('year',datetime(2017-01-01),datetime(2000-12-31)),
quarter = datetime_diff('quarter',datetime(2017-07-01),datetime(2017-03-30)),
month = datetime_diff('month',datetime(2017-01-01),datetime(2015-12-30)),
week = datetime_diff('week',datetime(2017-10-29 00:00),datetime(2017-09-30 23:59)),
day = datetime_diff('day',datetime(2017-10-29 00:00),datetime(2017-09-30 23:59)),
hour = datetime_diff('hour',datetime(2017-10-31 01:00),datetime(2017-10-30 23:59)),
minute = datetime_diff('minute',datetime(2017-10-30 23:05:01),datetime(2017-10-30 23:00:59)),
second = datetime_diff('second',datetime(2017-10-30 23:00:10.100),datetime(2017-10-30 23:00:00.900)),
millisecond = datetime_diff('millisecond',datetime(2017-10-30 23:00:00.200100),datetime(2017-10-30 23:00:00.100900)),
microsecond = datetime_diff('microsecond',datetime(2017-10-30 23:00:00.1009001),datetime(2017-10-30 23:00:00.1008009)),
nanosecond = datetime_diff('nanosecond',datetime(2017-10-30 23:00:00.0000000),datetime(2017-10-30 23:00:00.0000007))

documentation.title: datetime_local_to_utc()
documentation.description: Converts local datetime to UTC datetime using a time-zone specification.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a UTC datetime that corresponds the local datetime in the specified `timezone`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *from* | `datetime` |  *True* | The local datetime to convert.|
| *timezone* | `string` |  *True* | The timezone of the desired datetime. The value must be one of the supported timezones.|
documentation.example:
datatable(local_dt: datetime, tz: string)
[ datetime(2020-02-02 20:02:20), 'US/Pacific', 
  datetime(2020-02-02 20:02:20), 'America/Chicago', 
  datetime(2020-02-02 20:02:20), 'Europe/Paris']
| extend utc_dt = datetime_local_to_utc(local_dt, tz)

range Local from datetime(2022-03-27 01:00:00.0000000) to datetime(2022-03-27 04:00:00.0000000) step 1h
| extend UTC=datetime_local_to_utc(Local, 'Europe/Brussels')
| extend BackToLocal=datetime_utc_to_local(UTC, 'Europe/Brussels')
| extend diff=Local-BackToLocal

documentation.title: datetime_part()
documentation.description:
Extracts the requested date part as an integer value.

> **Deprecated aliases:** datepart()
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns an integer representing the extracted part.

> [!NOTE]
> `week_of_year` returns an integer which represents the week number. The week number is calculated from the first week of a year, which is the one that includes the first Thursday.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *part* | `string` |  *True* | Measurement of time to extract from *date*. See possible values.|
| *date* | `datetime` |  *True* | The full date from which to extract *part*. |

### Possible values of part

* Year
* Quarter
* Month
* week_of_year
* Day
* DayOfYear
* Hour
* Minute
* Second
* Millisecond
* Microsecond
* Nanosecond
documentation.example:
let dt = datetime(2017-10-30 01:02:03.7654321); 
print 
year = datetime_part("year", dt),
quarter = datetime_part("quarter", dt),
month = datetime_part("month", dt),
weekOfYear = datetime_part("week_of_year", dt),
day = datetime_part("day", dt),
dayOfYear = datetime_part("dayOfYear", dt),
hour = datetime_part("hour", dt),
minute = datetime_part("minute", dt),
second = datetime_part("second", dt),
millisecond = datetime_part("millisecond", dt),
microsecond = datetime_part("microsecond", dt),
nanosecond = datetime_part("nanosecond", dt)

documentation.title: datetime_utc_to_local()
documentation.description: Converts UTC datetime to local datetime using a time-zone specification.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a local datetime in the *timezone* that corresponds the UTC datetime.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *from* | `datetime` |  *True* | The UTC datetime to convert.|
| *timezone* | `string` |  *True* | The timezone to convert to. This value must be one of the supported timezones.|
documentation.example:
print dt=now()
| extend pacific_dt = datetime_utc_to_local(dt, 'US/Pacific'), canberra_dt = datetime_utc_to_local(dt, 'Australia/Canberra')
| extend diff = pacific_dt - canberra_dt

documentation.title: dcount_hll()
documentation.description:
Calculates the distinct count from results generated by hll or hll_merge.

Read about the underlying algorithm (*H*yper*L*og*L*og) and estimation accuracy.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the distinct count of each value in *hll*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*hll*| `string` | *True*| An expression generated by hll or hll-merge to be used to find the distinct count.|
documentation.example:
StormEvents
| summarize hllRes = hll(DamageProperty) by bin(StartTime,10m)
| summarize hllMerged = hll_merge(hllRes)
| project dcount_hll(hllMerged)

documentation.title: degrees()
documentation.description: Converts angle value in radians into value in degrees, using the formula `degrees = (180 / PI ) * angle_in_radians`.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the corresponding angle in degrees for an angle specified in radians.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *radians* | `real` |  *True* | The angle in radians to convert to degrees. |
documentation.example: print degrees0 = degrees(pi()/4), degrees1 = degrees(pi()*1.5), degrees2 = degrees(0)

documentation.title: dynamic_to_json()
documentation.description: Converts a scalar value of type `dynamic` to a canonical `string` representation.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a canonical representation of the input as a value of type `string`,
according to the following rules:

* If the input is a scalar value of type other than `dynamic`,
   the output is the application of `tostring()` to that value.

* If the input is an array of values, the output is composed of the
   characters `[`, `,`, and `]` interspersed with the canonical representation
   described here of each array element.

* If the input is a property bag, the output is composed of the characters
   `{`, `,`, and `}` interspersed with the colon (`:`)-delimited name/value pairs
   of the properties. The pairs are sorted by the names, and the values
   are in the canonical representation described here of each array element.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *expr* | `dynamic` |  *True* | The expression to convert to string representation.|

documentation.title: endofday()
documentation.description: Provides the end of the day containing the date, shifted by an offset, if provided.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a datetime representing the end of the day for the given *date* value, with the *offset*, if specified.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *date* | `datetime` |  *True*| The date to find the end of. |
| *offset* | `int` | | The number of offset days from *date*. Default is 0. |
documentation.example:
range offset from -1 to 1 step 1
 | project dayEnd = endofday(datetime(2017-01-01 10:10:17), offset)

documentation.title: endofmonth()
documentation.description: Provides the end of the month containing the date, shifted by an offset, if provided.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a datetime representing the end of the month for the given *date* value, with the *offset*, if specified.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *date* | `datetime` |  *True*| The date used to find the end of the month. |
| *offset* | `int` | | The number of offset months from *date*. Default is 0. |
documentation.example:
range offset from -1 to 1 step 1
 | project monthEnd = endofmonth(datetime(2017-01-01 10:10:17), offset)

documentation.title: endofweek()
documentation.description:
Provides the end of the week containing the date, shifted by an offset, if provided.

Last day of the week is considered to be a Saturday.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns datetime representing the end of the week for the given *date* value, with the *offset*, if specified.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *date* | `datetime` |  *True*| The date used to find the end of the week. |
| *offset* | `int` | | The number of offset weeks from *date*. Default is 0. |

documentation.title: endofyear()
documentation.description: Provides the end of the year containing the date, shifted by an offset, if provided.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns a datetime representing the end of the year for the given *date* value, with the &*offset*, if specified.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *date* | `datetime` |  *True*| The date used to find the end of the year. |
| *offset* | `int` | | The number of offset years from *date*. Default is 0. |
documentation.example:
range offset from -1 to 1 step 1
 | project yearEnd = endofyear(datetime(2017-01-01 10:10:17), offset)

documentation.title: erf()
documentation.description: Returns the error function of the input.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the error function of x.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *x* | `real` |  *True* | The value for which to calculate the function. |
documentation.example:
range x from -3 to 3 step 1
| extend erf_x = erf(x)

documentation.title: erfc()
documentation.description: Provides the complementary error function of the input.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the complementary error function of x.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *x* | `real` |  *True* | The value for which to calculate the function. |
documentation.example:
range x from -3 to 3 step 1
| extend erf_x = erfc(x)

documentation.title: estimate_data_size()
documentation.description: Provides an estimated data size in bytes for the selected columns of a tabular expression.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns the estimated data size in bytes of the referenced columns. Estimation is based on data types and actual values.
For example, the data size for the string `'{"a":"bcd"}'` is smaller than the dynamic value `dynamic({"a":"bcd"})`
because the latter's internal representation is more complex than that of a string.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*columns*| `string` | *True*|One or more comma-separated column references in the source tabular expression to use for data size estimation. To include all columns, use the wildcard (`*`) character.|
documentation.example:
range x from 1 to 10 step 1                    // x (long) is 8 
| extend Text = '1234567890'                   // Text length is 10  
| summarize Total=sum(estimate_data_size(*))   // (8+10)x10 = 180

documentation.title: exp()
documentation.description: The base-e exponential function of x, which is e raised to the power x: e^x.
documentation.returnInfo: The exponential value of x.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *x* | `real` |  *True*| The value of the exponent. |
documentation.example: print result = exp(2)

documentation.title: exp10()
documentation.description: The base-10 exponential function of x, which is 10 raised to the power x: 10^x.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the exponential value of x.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *x* | `real` |  *True*| The value of the exponent. |
documentation.example: print result = exp10(2)

documentation.title: exp2()
documentation.description: The base-2 exponential function of x, which is 2 raised to the power x: 2^x.
documentation.returnInfo: Returns the exponential value of x.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *x* | `real` |  *True*| The value of the exponent. |
documentation.example: print result = exp2(3)

documentation.title: extent_id()
documentation.description:
Provides a unique identifier for the data shard ("extent") containing the current record at the time the query was run.

Applying this function to calculated data that isn't attached to a data shard returns an empty guid (all zeros).

> **Deprecated aliases:** extentid()

> [!CAUTION]
>
> The value returned by this function isn't guaranteed to remain stable over time. The system continuously performs data grooming operations in the background
> and these can result with changes to existing extents and their IDs.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a value of type `guid` that identifies the current record's data shard at the time the query was run,
or an empty guid (all zeros).
documentation.example:
T
| where Timestamp > ago(1h)
| where ActivityId == 'dd0595d4-183e-494e-b88e-54c52fe90e5a'
| extend eid=extent_id()
| summarize by eid

documentation.title: extent_tags()
documentation.description:
Provides a dynamic array with the extent tags of the extent that the current record is in.

If you apply this function to calculated data, which isn't attached to a data shard, returns an empty value.
documentation.returnInfo:
Returns a value of type `dynamic` that is an array holding the current record's extent tags,
or an empty value.
documentation.example:
T
| where Timestamp > ago(1h)
| where ActivityId == 'dd0595d4-183e-494e-b88e-54c52fe90e5a'
| extend tags = extent_tags()
| summarize by tostring(tags)

T
| where Timestamp > ago(1h)
| extend Tags = extent_tags()
| where Tags has_cs 'MyTag' and Tags !has_cs 'drop-by:MyOtherTag'
| count

documentation.title: external_table()
documentation.description:
References an external table by name.

> [!NOTE]
>
> The `external_table` function has similar restrictions as the table function.
> Standard query limits apply to external table queries as well.

To accelerate queries over external delta tables, see Query acceleration policy.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *TableName* | `string` |  *True* | The name of the external table being queried. Must reference an external table of kind `blob`, `adl`, or `sql`.|
| *MappingName* | `string` | | A name of a mapping object that maps fields in the external data shards to columns output.|

The authentication method to access an external table is based on the connection string provided during its creation, and the permissions required to access the table vary depending on the authentication method. For more information, see Azure Storage external table or SQL Server external table.

documentation.title: extract()
documentation.description:
Get a match for a regular expression from a source string.

Optionally, convert the extracted substring to the indicated type.
documentation.returnInfo:
If *regex* finds a match in *source*: the substring matched against the indicated capture group *captureGroup*, optionally converted to *typeLiteral*.

If there's no match, or the type conversion fails: `null`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *regex* | `string` |  *True* | A regular expression.|
| *captureGroup* | `int` |  *True* | The capture group to extract. 0 stands for the entire match, 1 for the value matched by the first '('parenthesis')' in the regular expression, and 2 or more for subsequent parentheses.|
| *source* | `string` |  *True*| The string to search.|
| *typeLiteral* | `string` | | If provided, the extracted substring is converted to this type. For example, `typeof(long)`.

documentation.title: extract_all()
documentation.description:
Get all matches for a regular expression from a source string.
Optionally, retrieve a subset of matching groups.

```kusto
print extract_all(@"(\d+)", "a set of numbers: 123, 567 and 789") // results with the dynamic array ["123", "567", "789"]
```

> **Deprecated aliases:** extractall()
documentation.returnInfo:
* If *regex* finds a match in *source*: Returns dynamic array including all matches against the indicated capture groups *captureGroups*, or all of capturing groups in the *regex*.
* If number of *captureGroups* is 1: The returned array has a single dimension of matched values.
* If number of *captureGroups* is more than 1: The returned array is a two-dimensional collection of multi-value matches per *captureGroups* selection, or all capture groups present in the *regex* if *captureGroups* is omitted.
* If there's no match: `null`.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *regex* | `string` |  *True* | A regular expression containing between one and 16 capture groups.|
| *captureGroups* | `dynamic` | | An array that indicates the capture groups to extract. Valid values are from 1 to the number of capturing groups in the regular expression. Named capture groups are allowed as well. See examples.|
| *source* | `string` |  *True*| The string to search.|
documentation.example:
print Id="82b8be2d-dfa7-4bd1-8f63-24ad26d31449"
| extend guid_bytes = extract_all(@"([\da-f]{2})", Id) 

print Id="82b8be2d-dfa7-4bd1-8f63-24ad26d31449"
| extend guid_bytes = extract_all(@"(\w)(\w+)(\w)", Id)

print Id="82b8be2d-dfa7-4bd1-8f63-24ad26d31449"
| extend guid_bytes = extract_all(@"(\w)(\w+)(\w)", dynamic([1,3]), Id) 

print Id="82b8be2d-dfa7-4bd1-8f63-24ad26d31449"
| extend guid_bytes = extract_all(@"(?P<first>\w)(?P<middle>\w+)(?P<last>\w)", dynamic(['first',2,'last']), Id)

documentation.title: extract_json()
documentation.description:
Get a specified element out of a JSON text using a path expression.

Optionally convert the extracted string to a specific type.

> The `extract_json()` and `extractjson()` functions are equivalent
documentation.returnInfo: This function performs a JSONPath query into dataSource, which contains a valid JSON string, optionally converting that value to another type depending on the third argument.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *jsonPath* | `string` |  *True* | A JSONPath that defines an accessor into the JSON document.|
| *dataSource* | `string` |  *True* | A JSON document.|
| *type* | `string` | | An optional type literal. If provided, the extracted value is converted to this type. For example, `typeof(long)` will convert the extracted value to a `long`.|

* Apply where-clauses before using `extract_json()`.
* Consider using a regular expression match with extract instead. This can run very much faster, and is effective if the JSON is produced from a template.
* Use `parse_json()` if you need to extract more than one value from the JSON.
* Consider having the JSON parsed at ingestion by declaring the type of the column to be dynamic.
documentation.example:
let json = '{"name": "John", "age": 30, "city": "New York"}';
print extract_json("$.name", json, typeof(string));

documentation.title: format_bytes()
documentation.description: Formats a number as a string representing data size in bytes.
documentation.returnInfo: A string of *size* formatted as data size in bytes.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *size* | `real` |  *True* | The value to be formatted as data size in bytes.|
| *precision* | `int` | | The number of digits the value will be rounded to after the decimal point. The default is 0.|
| *units* | `string` | | The units of the target data size: `Bytes`, `KB`, `MB`, `GB`, `TB`, `PB`, or `EB`. If this parameter is empty, the units will be auto-selected based on input value.|
documentation.example:
print 
v1 = format_bytes(564),
v2 = format_bytes(10332, 1),
v3 = format_bytes(20010332),
v4 = format_bytes(20010332, 2),
v5 = format_bytes(20010332, 0, "KB")

documentation.title: format_datetime()
documentation.description: Formats a datetime according to the provided format.
documentation.returnInfo: A string with *date* formatted as specified by *format*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *date* | `datetime` |  *True* | The value to format.|
| *format* | `string` |  *True*| The output format comprised of one or more of the supported format elements.

### Supported format elements

The *format* parameter should include one or more of the following elements:

|Format specifier| Description| Examples|
|:--|:--|:--|
|`d`| The day of the month, from 1 through 31.| 2009-06-01T13:45:30 -> 1, 2009-06-15T13:45:30 -> 15
|`dd`| The day of the month, from 01 through 31.| 2009-06-01T13:45:30 -> 01, 2009-06-15T13:45:30 -> 15
|`f`| The tenths of a second in a date and time value.| 2009-06-15T13:45:30.6170000 -> 6, 2009-06-15T13:45:30.05 -> 0
|`ff`| The hundredths of a second in a date and time value.| 2009-06-15T13:45:30.6170000 -> 61, 2009-06-15T13:45:30.0050000 -> 00
|`fff`| The milliseconds in a date and time value.| 6/15/2009 13:45:30.617 -> 617, 6/15/2009 13:45:30.0005 -> 000
|`ffff`| The ten thousandths of a second in a date and time value.| 2009-06-15T13:45:30.6175000 -> 6175, 2009-06-15T13:45:30.0000500 -> 0000
|`fffff`| The hundred thousandths of a second in a date and time value. |2009-06-15T13:45:30.6175400 -> 61754, 2009-06-15T13:45:30.000005 -> 00000
|`ffffff`| The millionths of a second in a date and time value.| 2009-06-15T13:45:30.6175420 -> 617542, 2009-06-15T13:45:30.0000005 -> 000000
|`fffffff`| The ten millionths of a second in a date and time value.| 2009-06-15T13:45:30.6175425 -> 6175425, 2009-06-15T13:45:30.0001150 -> 0001150
|`F`| If non-zero, the tenths of a second in a date and time value.| 2009-06-15T13:45:30.6170000 -> 6, 2009-06-15T13:45:30.0500000 -> (no output)
|`FF`| If non-zero, the hundredths of a second in a date and time value.| 2009-06-15T13:45:30.6170000 -> 61, 2009-06-15T13:45:30.0050000 -> (no output)
|`FFF`| If non-zero, the milliseconds in a date and time value.| 2009-06-15T13:45:30.6170000 -> 617, 2009-06-15T13:45:30.0005000 -> (no output)
|`FFFF`| If non-zero, the ten thousandths of a second in a date and time value.|2009-06-15T13:45:30.5275000 -> 5275, 2009-06-15T13:45:30.0000500 -> (no output)
|`FFFFF`| If non-zero, the hundred thousandths of a second in a date and time value.| 2009-06-15T13:45:30.6175400 -> 61754, 2009-06-15T13:45:30.0000050 -> (no output)
|`FFFFFF`| If non-zero, the millionths of a second in a date and time value.| 2009-06-15T13:45:30.6175420 -> 617542, 2009-06-15T13:45:30.0000005 -> (no output)
|`FFFFFFF`| If non-zero, the ten millionths of a second in a date and time value.| 2009-06-15T13:45:30.6175425 -> 6175425, 2009-06-15T13:45:30.0001150 -> 000115
|`h`| The hour, using a 12-hour clock from 1 to 12.| 2009-06-15T01:45:30 -> 1, 2009-06-15T13:45:30 -> 1
|`hh`| The hour, using a 12-hour clock from 01 to 12.| 2009-06-15T01:45:30 -> 01, 2009-06-15T13:45:30 -> 01
|`H`| The hour, using a 24-hour clock from 0 to 23.| 2009-06-15T01:45:30 -> 1, 2009-06-15T13:45:30 -> 13
|`HH`| The hour, using a 24-hour clock from 00 to 23.| 2009-06-15T01:45:30 -> 01, 2009-06-15T13:45:30 -> 13
|`m`| The minute, from 0 through 59.| 2009-06-15T01:09:30 -> 9, 2009-06-15T13:29:30 -> 29
|`mm`| The minute, from 00 through 59.| 2009-06-15T01:09:30 -> 09, 2009-06-15T01:45:30 -> 45
|`M`| The month, from 1 through 12.| 2009-06-15T13:45:30 -> 6
|`MM`| The month, from 01 through 12.| 2009-06-15T13:45:30 -> 06
|`s`| The second, from 0 through 59.| 2009-06-15T13:45:09 -> 9
|`ss`| The second, from 00 through 59.| 2009-06-15T13:45:09 -> 09
|`y`| The year, from 0 to 99.| 0001-01-01T00:00:00 -> 1, 0900-01-01T00:00:00 -> 0, 1900-01-01T00:00:00 -> 0, 2009-06-15T13:45:30 -> 9, 2019-06-15T13:45:30 -> 19
|`yy`| The year, from 00 to 99.| 0001-01-01T00:00:00 -> 01, 0900-01-01T00:00:00 -> 00, 1900-01-01T00:00:00 -> 00, 2019-06-15T13:45:30 -> 19
|`yyyy`| The year as a four-digit number.| 0001-01-01T00:00:00 -> 0001, 0900-01-01T00:00:00 -> 0900, 1900-01-01T00:00:00 -> 1900, 2009-06-15T13:45:30 -> 2009
|`tt`| AM / PM hours| 2009-06-15T13:45:09 -> PM

### Supported delimiters

The format specifier can include the following delimiters:

|Delimiter|Comment|
|:---------|:-------|
|`' '`| Space|
|`'/'`||
|`'-'`|Dash|
|`':'`||
|`','`||
|`'.'`||
|`'_'`||
|`'['`||
|`']'`||

documentation.title: format_ipv4()
documentation.description: Parses the input with a netmask and returns a string representing the IPv4 address.
documentation.returnInfo:
If conversion is successful, the result will be a string representing IPv4 address.
If conversion isn't successful, the result will be an empty string.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *ip* | `string` |  *True* | The IPv4 address. The format may be a string or number representation in big-endian order.|
| *prefix* | `int` | | An integer from 0 to 32 representing the number of most-significant bits that are taken into account. If unspecified, all 32 bit-masks are used.|
documentation.example:
datatable(address:string, mask:long)
[
 '192.168.1.1', 24,          
 '192.168.1.1', 32,          
 '192.168.1.1/24', 32,       
 '192.168.1.1/24', long(-1), 
]
| extend result = format_ipv4(address, mask), 
         result_mask = format_ipv4_mask(address, mask)

documentation.title: format_ipv4_mask()
documentation.description: Parses the input with a netmask and returns a string representing the IPv4 address in CIDR notation.
documentation.returnInfo:
If conversion is successful, the result will be a string representing IPv4 address as CIDR notation.
If conversion isn't successful, the result will be an empty string.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *ip* | `string` |  *True* | The IPv4 address as CIDR notation. The format may be a string or number representation in big-endian order.|
| *prefix* | `int` | | An integer from 0 to 32 representing the number of most-significant bits that are taken into account. If unspecified, all 32 bit-masks are used.|
documentation.example:
datatable(address:string, mask:long)
[
 '192.168.1.1', 24,          
 '192.168.1.1', 32,          
 '192.168.1.1/24', 32,       
 '192.168.1.1/24', long(-1), 
]
| extend result = format_ipv4(address, mask), 
         result_mask = format_ipv4_mask(address, mask)

documentation.title: format_timespan()
documentation.description: Formats a timespan according to the provided format.
documentation.returnInfo: A string with *timespan* formatted as specified by *format*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *timespan* | `timespan` |  *True* | The value to format.|
| *format* | `string` |  *True*| The output format comprised of one or more of the supported format elements.

### Supported format elements

|Format specifier| Description| Examples
|:---|:---|:---
|`d`-`dddddddd`| The number of whole days in the time interval. Padded with zeros if needed.| 15.13:45:30: d -> 15, dd -> 15, ddd -> 015
|`f`| The tenths of a second in the time interval.| 15.13:45:30.6170000 -> 6, 15.13:45:30.05 -> 0
|`ff`| The hundredths of a second in the time interval.| 15.13:45:30.6170000 -> 61, 15.13:45:30.0050000 -> 00
|`fff`| The milliseconds in the time interval.| 6/15/2009 13:45:30.617 -> 617, 6/15/2009 13:45:30.0005 -> 000
|`ffff`| The ten thousandths of a second in the time interval.| 15.13:45:30.6175000 -> 6175, 15.13:45:30.0000500 -> 0000
|`fffff`| The hundred thousandths of a second in the time interval.| 15.13:45:30.6175400 -> 61754, 15.13:45:30.000005 -> 00000
|`ffffff`| The millionths of a second in the time interval.| 15.13:45:30.6175420 -> 617542, 15.13:45:30.0000005 -> 000000
|`fffffff`| The ten millionths of a second in the time interval.| 15.13:45:30.6175425 -> 6175425, 15.13:45:30.0001150 -> 0001150
|`F`| If non-zero, the tenths of a second in the time interval.| 15.13:45:30.6170000 -> 6, 15.13:45:30.0500000 -> (no output)
|`FF`| If non-zero, the hundredths of a second in the time interval.| 15.13:45:30.6170000 -> 61, 15.13:45:30.0050000 -> (no output)
|`FFF`| If non-zero, the milliseconds in the time interval.| 15.13:45:30.6170000 -> 617, 15.13:45:30.0005000 -> (no output)
|`FFFF`| If non-zero, the ten thousandths of a second in the time interval. |15.13:45:30.5275000 -> 5275, 15.13:45:30.0000500 -> (no output)
|`FFFFF`| If non-zero, the hundred thousandths of a second in the time interval.| 15.13:45:30.6175400 -> 61754, 15.13:45:30.0000050 -> (no output)
|`FFFFFF`| If non-zero, the millionths of a second in the time interval.| 15.13:45:30.6175420 -> 617542, 15.13:45:30.0000005 -> (no output)
|`FFFFFFF`| If non-zero, the ten millionths of a second in the time interval.| 15.13:45:30.6175425 -> 6175425, 15.13:45:30.0001150 -> 000115
|`H`| The hour, using a 24-hour clock from 0 to 23.| 15.01:45:30 -> 1, 15.13:45:30 -> 13
|`HH`| The hour, using a 24-hour clock from 00 to 23.| 15.01:45:30 -> 01, 15.13:45:30 -> 13
|`m`| The number of whole minutes in the time interval that aren't included as part of hours or days. Single-digit minutes don't have a leading zero.| 15.01:09:30 -> 9, 15.13:29:30 -> 29
|`mm`| The number of whole minutes in the time interval that aren't included as part of hours or days. Single-digit minutes have a leading zero.| 15.01:09:30 -> 09, 15.01:45:30 -> 45
|`s`| The number of whole seconds in the time interval that aren't included as part of hours, days, or minutes. Single-digit seconds don't have a leading zero.| 15.13:45:09 -> 9
|`ss`|The number of whole seconds in the time interval that aren't included as part of hours, days, or minutes. Single-digit seconds have a leading zero.| 15.13:45:09 -> 09

### Supported delimiters

The format specifier can include following delimiters:

|Delimiter|Comment|
|:---------|:-------|
|`' '`| Space|
|`'/'`||
|`'-'`|Dash|
|`':'`||
|`','`||
|`'.'`||
|`'_'`||
|`'['`||
|`']'`||
documentation.example:
let t = time(29.09:00:05.12345);
print 
v1=format_timespan(t, 'dd.hh:mm:ss:FF'),
v2=format_timespan(t, 'ddd.h:mm:ss [fffffff]')

documentation.returnInfo: Gamma function of *number*.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|

documentation.title: geo_angle()
documentation.description: Calculates clockwise angle in radians between two lines on Earth. The first line is [point1, point2] and the second line is [point2, point3].
documentation.returnInfo:
An angle in radians in range [0, 2pi) between two lines [p1, p2] and [p2, p3]. The angle is measured CW from the first line to the Second line.

> [!NOTE]
>
> * The geospatial coordinates are interpreted as represented by the WGS-84 coordinate reference system.
> * The geodetic datum used to measure distance on Earth is a sphere. Line edges are geodesics on the sphere.
> * If the coordinates are invalid, the query will produce a null result.
> * If point1 is equal to point2, the query will produce a null result.
> * If point2 is equal to point3, the query will produce a null result.
> * If point1 and point2 are antipodal, the query will produce a null result.
> * If point2 and point3 are antipodal, the query will produce a null result.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*p1_longitude*| `real` |  *True* | The longitude value in degrees of the first geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-180, +180].|
|*p1_latitude*| `real` |  *True* | The latitude value in degrees of the first geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-90, +90].|
|*p2_longitude*| `real` |  *True* | The longitude value in degrees of the second geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-180, +180].|
|*p2_latitude*| `real` |  *True* | The latitude value in degrees of the second geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-90, +90].|
|*p3_longitude*| `real` |  *True* | The longitude value in degrees of the second geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-180, +180].|
|*p3_latitude*| `real` |  *True* | The latitude value in degrees of the second geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-90, +90].|
documentation.example:
print angle_in_radians = geo_angle(0, 10, 0,5, 3,-10)

let angle_in_radians = geo_angle(0, 10, 0,5, 3,-10);
print angle_in_degrees = degrees(angle_in_radians)

print is_null = isnull(geo_angle(0, 10, 0, 10, 3, -10))

documentation.title: geo_azimuth()
documentation.description: Calculates clockwise angle in radians between the line from point1 to true north and a line from point1 to point2 on Earth.
documentation.returnInfo:
An angle in radians between the line from point p1 to true north and line [p1, p2]. The angle is measured clockwise.

> [!NOTE]
>
> * The geospatial coordinates are interpreted as represented by the WGS-84 coordinate reference system.
> * The geodetic datum used to measure distance on Earth is a sphere. Line edges are geodesics on the sphere.
> * Azimuth 0 points north. Azimuth Pi/2 points east. Azimuth Pi points south. Azimuth 3Pi/2 points west.
> * If the coordinates are invalid, the query will produce a null result.
> * If point1 is equal to point2, the query will produce a null result.
> * If point1 and point2 are antipodal, the query will produce a null result.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*p1_longitude*| `real` |  *True* | The longitude value in degrees of the first geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-180, +180].|
|*p1_latitude*| `real` |  *True* | The latitude value in degrees of the first geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-90, +90].|
|*p2_longitude*| `real` |  *True* | The longitude value in degrees of the second geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-180, +180].|
|*p2_latitude*| `real` |  *True* | The latitude value in degrees of the second geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-90, +90].|
documentation.example:
print azimuth_in_radians = geo_azimuth(5, 10, 10, -40)

let azimuth_in_radians = geo_azimuth(5, 10, 10, -40);
print azimuth_in_degrees = degrees(azimuth_in_radians);

let get_direction = (azimuth:real)
{
    let pi = pi();
    iff(azimuth < pi/2,   "North-East",
    iff(azimuth < pi,     "South-East",
    iff(azimuth < 3*pi/2, "South-West",
                          "North-West")));
};
datatable(timestamp:datetime, lng:real, lat:real)
[
    datetime(2024-01-01T00:01:53.048506Z), -115.4036607693417, 36.40551631046261,
    datetime(2024-01-01T00:02:53.048506Z), -115.3256807623232, 36.34102142760111,
    datetime(2024-01-01T00:03:53.048506Z), -115.2732290602112, 36.28458914829917,
    datetime(2024-01-01T00:04:53.048506Z), -115.2513186233914, 36.27622394664352,
    datetime(2024-01-01T00:05:53.048506Z), -115.2352055633212, 36.27545547038515,
    datetime(2024-01-01T00:06:53.048506Z), -115.1894341934856, 36.28266934431671,
    datetime(2024-01-01T00:07:53.048506Z), -115.1054318118468, 36.28957085435267,
    datetime(2024-01-01T00:08:53.048506Z), -115.0648614339413, 36.28110743285072,
    datetime(2024-01-01T00:09:53.048506Z), -114.9858032867736, 36.29780696509714,
    datetime(2024-01-01T00:10:53.048506Z), -114.9016966527561, 36.36556196813566,
]
| sort by timestamp asc 
| extend prev_lng = prev(lng), prev_lat = prev(lat)
| where isnotnull(prev_lng) and isnotnull(prev_lat)
| extend direction = get_direction(geo_azimuth(prev_lng, prev_lat, lng, lat))
| project direction, lng, lat
| render scatterchart with (kind = map)

print is_null = isnull(geo_azimuth(5, 10, 5, 10))

documentation.title: geo_closest_point_on_line()
documentation.description: Calculates a point on a line or a multiline, which is closest to a given point on Earth.
documentation.returnInfo:
A point in GeoJSON Format and of a dynamic data type on a line or multiline which is the closest to a given point on Earth. If the coordinate or lineString are invalid, the query produces a null result.

> [!NOTE]
>
> * The geospatial coordinates are interpreted as represented by the WGS-84 coordinate reference system.
> * The geodetic datum used to measure distance on Earth is a sphere. Line edges are geodesics on the sphere.
> * If input line edges are straight cartesian lines, consider using geo_line_densify() in order to convert planar edges to geodesics.
> * In order to calculate a distance between the closest point on a line or multiline to a given point, use geo_distance_point_to_line()

### LineString definition and constraints

dynamic({"type": "LineString","coordinates": [[lng_1,lat_1], [lng_2,lat_2],..., [lng_N,lat_N]]})

dynamic({"type": "MultiLineString","coordinates": [[line_1, line_2, ..., line_N]]})

* LineString coordinates array must contain at least two entries.
* Coordinates [longitude, latitude] must be valid where longitude is a real number in the range [-180, +180] and latitude is a real number in the range [-90, +90].
* Edge length must be less than 180 degrees. The shortest edge between the two vertices is chosen.

> [!TIP]
>
> * Using literal LineString or a MultiLineString may result in better performance.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *longitude* | `real` |  *True* | The geospatial coordinate longitude value in degrees. A valid value is in the range [-180, +180].|
| *latitude* | `real` |  *True* | The geospatial coordinate latitude value in degrees. A valid value is in the range [-90, +90].|
| *lineString* | `dynamic` |  *True* | A line or multiline in the GeoJSON format.|

documentation.title: geo_closest_point_on_polygon()
documentation.description: Calculates a point on a polygon or a multipolygon, which is closest to a given point on Earth.
documentation.returnInfo:
A point in GeoJSON Format and of a dynamic data type on a polygon or multipolygon which is the closest to a given point on Earth. If polygon contains input point, the result with be the same point. If the coordinates or polygons are invalid, the query produces a null result.

> [!NOTE]
>
> * The geospatial coordinates are interpreted as represented by the WGS-84 coordinate reference system.
> * The geodetic datum used for measurements on Earth is a sphere. Polygon edges are geodesics on the sphere.
> * If input polygon edges are straight cartesian lines, consider using geo_polygon_densify() to convert planar edges to geodesics.
> * In order to calculate a distance between the closest point on a polygon or multipolygon to a given point, use geo_distance_point_to_polygon()

**Polygon definition and constraints**

dynamic({"type": "Polygon","coordinates": [LinearRingShell, LinearRingHole_1, ..., LinearRingHole_N]})

dynamic({"type": "MultiPolygon","coordinates": [[LinearRingShell, LinearRingHole_1,..., LinearRingHole_N],..., [LinearRingShell, LinearRingHole_1,..., LinearRingHole_M]]})

* LinearRingShell is required and defined as a `counterclockwise` ordered array of coordinates [[lng_1,lat_1],...,[lng_i,lat_i],...,[lng_j,lat_j],...,[lng_1,lat_1]]. There can be only one shell.
* LinearRingHole is optional and defined as a `clockwise` ordered array of coordinates [[lng_1,lat_1],...,[lng_i,lat_i],...,[lng_j,lat_j],...,[lng_1,lat_1]]. There can be any number of interior rings and holes.
* LinearRing vertices must be distinct with at least three coordinates. The first coordinate must be equal to the last. At least four entries are required.
* Coordinates [longitude, latitude] must be valid. Longitude must be a real number in the range [-180, +180] and latitude must be a real number in the range [-90, +90].
* LinearRingShell encloses at most half of the sphere. LinearRing divides the sphere into two regions. The smaller of the two regions will be chosen.
* LinearRing edge length must be less than 180 degrees. The shortest edge between the two vertices will be chosen.
* LinearRings must not cross and must not share edges. LinearRings may share vertices.
* Polygon doesn't necessarily contain its vertices.

> [!TIP]
>
> * Using literal polygons may result in better performance.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *longitude* | `real` |  *True* | Geospatial coordinate, longitude value in degrees. Valid value is a real number and in the range [-180, +180].|
| *latitude* | `real` |  *True* | Geospatial coordinate, latitude value in degrees. Valid value is a real number and in the range [-90, +90].|
| *polygon* | `dynamic` |  *True* | Polygon or multipolygon in the GeoJSON format.|
documentation.example:
let central_park = dynamic({"type":"Polygon","coordinates":[[[-73.9495,40.7969],[-73.95807266235352,40.80068603561921],[-73.98201942443848,40.76825672305777],[-73.97317886352539,40.76455136505513],[-73.9495,40.7969]]]});
print geo_closest_point_on_polygon(-73.9839, 40.7705, central_park)

print result = isnull(geo_closest_point_on_polygon(500,1,dynamic({"type": "Polygon","coordinates": [[[0,0],[10,10],[10,1],[0,0]]]})))

print result = isnull(geo_closest_point_on_polygon(1,1,dynamic({"type": "Polygon","coordinates": [[[0,0],[10,10],[10,10],[0,0]]]})))

documentation.title: geo_distance_2points()
documentation.description: Calculates the shortest distance in meters between two geospatial coordinates on Earth.
documentation.returnInfo:
The shortest distance, in meters, between two geographic locations on Earth. If the coordinates are invalid, the query produces a null result.

> [!NOTE]
>
> * The geospatial coordinates are interpreted as represented by the WGS-84 coordinate reference system.
> * Most applications should measure distance using sphere ('use_spheroid' = false) which is more performant. If extra precision is needed, 'use_spheroid' option can be set to 'true', for extra precision, which might be more relevant for bigger distances, which might get impacted due to earth curvature.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
|*p1_longitude*| `real` |  *True* | The longitude value in degrees of the first geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-180, +180].|
|*p1_latitude*| `real` |  *True* | The latitude value in degrees of the first geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-90, +90].|
|*p2_longitude*| `real` |  *True* | The longitude value in degrees of the second geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-180, +180].|
|*p2_latitude*| `real` |  *True* | The latitude value in degrees of the second geospatial coordinate. A valid value is in the range [-90, +90].|
|*use_spheroid*| `bool` | | If `false` will use a sphere as geodetic datum for measuring distance. If `true` will measure distance using spheroid. If unspecified, the default value `false` is used.
documentation.example:
print distance_in_meters = geo_distance_2points(-122.407628, 47.578557, -118.275287, 34.019056)

range i from 1 to 1000000 step 1
| project lng = rand() * real(-122), lat = rand() * 90
| where lng between(real(-122) .. 0) and lat between(47 .. 90)
| where geo_distance_point_to_line(lng,lat,dynamic({"type":"LineString","coordinates":[[-122,47],[0,51]]})) < 500
| render scatterchart with (kind=map)

StormEvents
| extend distance_1_to_11m = geo_distance_2points(BeginLon, BeginLat, EndLon, EndLat)
| where distance_1_to_11m between (1 .. 11)
| project distance_1_to_11m

print distance = geo_distance_2points(300,1,1,1)

documentation.title: geo_distance_point_to_line()
documentation.description: Calculates the shortest distance in meters between a coordinate and a line or multiline on Earth.
documentation.returnInfo:
The shortest distance, in meters, between a coordinate and a line or multiline on Earth. If the coordinate or lineString are invalid, the query produces a null result.

> [!NOTE]
>
> * The geospatial coordinates are interpreted as represented by the WGS-84 coordinate reference system.
> * The geodetic datum used to measure distance on Earth is a sphere. Line edges are geodesics on the sphere.
> * If input line edges are straight cartesian lines, consider using geo_line_densify() in order to convert planar edges to geodesics.

### LineString definition and constraints

dynamic({"type": "LineString","coordinates": [[lng_1,lat_1], [lng_2,lat_2],..., [lng_N,lat_N]]})

dynamic({"type": "MultiLineString","coordinates": [[line_1, line_2, ..., line_N]]})

* LineString coordinates array must contain at least two entries.
* Coordinates [longitude, latitude] must be valid where longitude is a real number in the range [-180, +180] and latitude is a real number in the range [-90, +90].
* Edge length must be less than 180 degrees. The shortest edge between the two vertices is chosen.

> [!TIP]
>
> * Using literal LineString or a MultiLineString may result in better performance.
> * If you want to know the shortest distance between one or more points to many lines, consider folding these lines into one multiline. See the following example.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *longitude* | `real` |  *True* | The geospatial coordinate longitude value in degrees. A valid value is in the range [-180, +180].|
| *latitude* | `real` |  *True* | The geospatial coordinate latitude value in degrees. A valid value is in the range [-90, +90].|
| *lineString* | `dynamic` |  *True* | A line or multiline in the GeoJSON format.|

documentation.title: geo_distance_point_to_polygon()
documentation.description: Calculates the shortest distance between a coordinate and a polygon or a multipolygon on Earth.
documentation.returnInfo:
The shortest distance, in meters, between a coordinate and a polygon or a multipolygon on Earth. If polygon contains point, the distance will be 0. If the coordinates or polygons are invalid, the query will produce a null result.

> [!NOTE]
>
> * The geospatial coordinates are interpreted as represented by the WGS-84 coordinate reference system.
> * The geodetic datum used for measurements on Earth is a sphere. Polygon edges are geodesics on the sphere.
> * If input polygon edges are straight cartesian lines, consider using geo_polygon_densify() to convert planar edges to geodesics.

**Polygon definition and constraints**

dynamic({"type": "Polygon","coordinates": [LinearRingShell, LinearRingHole_1, ..., LinearRingHole_N]})

dynamic({"type": "MultiPolygon","coordinates": [[LinearRingShell, LinearRingHole_1,..., LinearRingHole_N],..., [LinearRingShell, LinearRingHole_1,..., LinearRingHole_M]]})

* LinearRingShell is required and defined as a `counterclockwise` ordered array of coordinates [[lng_1,lat_1],...,[lng_i,lat_i],...,[lng_j,lat_j],...,[lng_1,lat_1]]. There can be only one shell.
* LinearRingHole is optional and defined as a `clockwise` ordered array of coordinates [[lng_1,lat_1],...,[lng_i,lat_i],...,[lng_j,lat_j],...,[lng_1,lat_1]]. There can be any number of interior rings and holes.
* LinearRing vertices must be distinct with at least three coordinates. The first coordinate must be equal to the last. At least four entries are required.
* Coordinates [longitude, latitude] must be valid. Longitude must be a real number in the range [-180, +180] and latitude must be a real number in the range [-90, +90].
* LinearRingShell encloses at most half of the sphere. LinearRing divides the sphere into two regions. The smaller of the two regions will be chosen.
* LinearRing edge length must be less than 180 degrees. The shortest edge between the two vertices will be chosen.
* LinearRings must not cross and must not share edges. LinearRings may share vertices.
* Polygon doesn't necessarily contain its vertices.

> [!TIP]
>
> * Using literal polygons may result in better performance.
> * If you want to know if polygon contains point, see geo_point_in_polygon()
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *longitude* | `real` |  *True* | Geospatial coordinate, longitude value in degrees. Valid value is a real number and in the range [-180, +180].|
| *latitude* | `real` |  *True* | Geospatial coordinate, latitude value in degrees. Valid value is a real number and in the range [-90, +90].|
| *polygon* | `dynamic` |  *True* | Polygon or multipolygon in the GeoJSON format.|

documentation.title: geo_from_wkt()
documentation.description: Converts Well-known text (WKT) string to GeoJSON shape.
documentation.returnInfo:
Shape in GeoJSON Format and of a dynamic data type. If the input WKT string is invalid or unsupported, the query produces a null result.

> [!NOTE]
>
> The geospatial coordinates are interpreted as represented by the WGS-84 coordinate reference system.

> [!TIP]
>
> * Using converted and stored GeoJSON shapes may result in better performance in geospatial analysis.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *wkt* | `string` |  *True* | Well-known text representation string of geometry.|

documentation.title: geo_geohash_neighbors()
documentation.description:
Calculates Geohash neighbors.

Read more about `geohash`.
documentation.returnInfo: An array of Geohash neighbors. If the Geohash is invalid, the query produces a null result.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *geohash* | `string` |  *True* | A geohash value as it was calculated by geo_point_to_geohash(). The geohash string must be between 1 and 18 characters.|
documentation.example:
print neighbors = geo_geohash_neighbors('sunny')

let geohash = 'sunny';
print cells = array_concat(pack_array(geohash), geo_geohash_neighbors(geohash))

let geohash = 'sunny';
print cells = array_concat(pack_array(geohash), geo_geohash_neighbors(geohash))
| mv-expand cells to typeof(string)
| project polygons = geo_geohash_to_polygon(cells)
| summarize arr = make_list(polygons)
| project geojson = bag_pack("type", "Feature","geometry", bag_pack("type", "GeometryCollection", "geometries", arr), "properties", bag_pack("name", "polygons"))

let h3cell = 'sunny';
print cells = array_concat(pack_array(h3cell), geo_geohash_neighbors(h3cell))
| mv-expand cells to typeof(string)
| project polygons = geo_geohash_to_polygon(cells)
| summarize arr = make_list(polygons)
| project polygon = geo_union_polygons_array(arr)

print invalid = isnull(geo_geohash_neighbors('a'))

documentation.title: geo_geohash_to_central_point()
documentation.description:
Calculates the geospatial coordinates that represent the center of a geohash rectangular area.

Read more about `geohash`.
documentation.returnInfo:
The geospatial coordinate values in GeoJSON Format and of a dynamic data type. If the geohash is invalid, the query will produce a null result.

> [!NOTE]
> The GeoJSON format specifies longitude first and latitude second.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *geohash* | `string` |  *True* | A geohash value as it was calculated by geo_point_to_geohash(). The geohash string must be between 1 and 18 characters.|
documentation.example:
print point = geo_geohash_to_central_point("sunny")
| extend coordinates = point.coordinates
| extend longitude = coordinates[0], latitude = coordinates[1]

print geohash = geo_geohash_to_central_point("a")

documentation.title: geo_geohash_to_polygon()
documentation.description:
Calculates the polygon that represents the geohash rectangular area.

Read more about geohash.
documentation.returnInfo:
Polygon in GeoJSON Format and of a dynamic data type. If the geohash is invalid, the query will produce a null result.

> [!NOTE]
> Geohash edges are straight lines and aren't geodesics. If the geohash polygon is part of some other calculation, consider densifying it with geo_polygon_densify().
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *geohash* | `string` |  *True* | A geohash value as it was calculated by geo_point_to_geohash(). The geohash string must be between 1 and 18 characters.|
documentation.example:
print GeohashPolygon = geo_geohash_to_polygon("dr5ru");

// Geohash GeoJSON collection
datatable(lng:real, lat:real)
[
    -73.975212, 40.789608,
    -73.916869, 40.818314,
    -73.989148, 40.743273,
]
| project geohash = geo_point_to_geohash(lng, lat, 5)
| project geohash_polygon = geo_geohash_to_polygon(geohash)
| summarize geohash_polygon_lst = make_list(geohash_polygon)
| project bag_pack(
    "type", "Feature",
    "geometry", bag_pack("type", "GeometryCollection", "geometries", geohash_polygon_lst),
    "properties", bag_pack("name", "Geohash polygons collection"))

print GeohashPolygon = geo_geohash_to_polygon("a");

documentation.title: geo_h3cell_children()
documentation.description:
Calculates the H3 cell children.

Read more about H3 Cell.
documentation.returnInfo:
Array of H3 Cell children tokens. If the H3 Cell is invalid or child resolution is lower than given cell, the query will produce a null result.

> [!NOTE]
>
> A difference between cell resolution and its children can't be more than 5. A difference of 5 levels will be resulted in up to 16807 children tokens.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *h3cell* | `string` |  *True* | An H3 Cell token value as it was calculated by geo_point_to_h3cell().|
| *resolution* | `int` | | Defines the requested children cells resolution. Supported values are in the range [1, 15]. If unspecified, an immediate children token will be calculated.|
documentation.example:
print children = geo_h3cell_children('862a1072fffffff')

let h3_cell = '862a1072fffffff'; 
print children_count = array_length(geo_h3cell_children(h3_cell, geo_h3cell_level(h3_cell) + 3))

print children = geo_h3cell_children('862a1072fffffff')
| mv-expand children to typeof(string)
| project child = geo_h3cell_to_polygon(children)
| summarize h3_hash_polygon_lst = make_list(child)
| project geojson = bag_pack(
    "type", "Feature",
    "geometry", bag_pack("type", "GeometryCollection", "geometries", h3_hash_polygon_lst),
    "properties", bag_pack("name", "H3 polygons collection"))

print is_null = isnull(geo_h3cell_children('abc'))

print is_null = isnull(geo_h3cell_children(geo_point_to_h3cell(1, 1, 9), 15))

documentation.title: geo_h3cell_level()
documentation.description:
Calculates the H3 cell resolution.

Read more about H3 Cell.
documentation.returnInfo: An integer that represents H3 Cell level. Valid level is in range [0, 15]. If the H3 Cell is invalid, the query will produce a null result.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *h3cell* | `string` |  *True* | An H3 Cell token value as it was calculated by geo_point_to_h3cell().|
documentation.example:
print cell_res = geo_h3cell_level('862a1072fffffff')

print cell_res = geo_h3cell_level(geo_point_to_h3cell(1,1,10))

print invalid_res = isnull(geo_h3cell_level('abc'))

documentation.title: geo_h3cell_neighbors()
documentation.description:
Calculates the H3 cell neighbors.

Read more about H3 Cell.
documentation.returnInfo:
An array of H3 cell neighbors. If the H3 Cell is invalid, the query will produce a null result.

> [!NOTE]
> If more than immidiate neighbors are needed, please see geo_h3cell_rings().
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *h3cell* | `string` |  *True* | An H3 Cell token value as it was calculated by geo_point_to_h3cell().|
documentation.example:
print neighbors = geo_h3cell_neighbors('862a1072fffffff')

let h3cell = '862a1072fffffff';
print cells = array_concat(pack_array(h3cell), geo_h3cell_neighbors(h3cell))

let h3cell = '862a1072fffffff';
print cells = array_concat(pack_array(h3cell), geo_h3cell_neighbors(h3cell))
| mv-expand cells to typeof(string)
| project polygons = geo_h3cell_to_polygon(cells)
| summarize arr = make_list(polygons)
| project geojson = bag_pack("type", "Feature","geometry", bag_pack("type", "GeometryCollection", "geometries", arr), "properties", bag_pack("name", "polygons"))

let h3cell = '862a1072fffffff';
print cells = array_concat(pack_array(h3cell), geo_h3cell_neighbors(h3cell))
| mv-expand cells to typeof(string)
| project polygons = geo_h3cell_to_polygon(cells)
| summarize arr = make_list(polygons)
| project polygon = geo_union_polygons_array(arr)

print invalid = isnull(geo_h3cell_neighbors('abc'))

documentation.title: geo_h3cell_parent()
documentation.description:
Calculates the H3 cell parent.

Read more about H3 Cell.
documentation.returnInfo: H3 Cell parent token `string`. If the H3 Cell is invalid or parent resolution is higher than given cell, the query will produce an empty result.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *h3cell* | `string` |  *True* | An H3 Cell token value as it was calculated by geo_point_to_h3cell().|
| *resolution* | `int` | | Defines the requested children cells resolution. Supported values are in the range [0, 14]. If unspecified, an immediate children token will be calculated.|
documentation.example:
print parent_cell = geo_h3cell_parent('862a1072fffffff')

print parent_cell = geo_h3cell_parent('862a1072fffffff', 1)

print parent_res = geo_h3cell_level(geo_h3cell_parent((geo_point_to_h3cell(1,1,10))))

print parent_res = geo_h3cell_level(geo_h3cell_parent(geo_point_to_h3cell(1,1,10), 3))

print invalid = isempty(geo_h3cell_parent('123'))

print invalid = isempty(geo_h3cell_parent('862a1072fffffff', 100))

print invalid = isempty(geo_h3cell_parent('862a1072fffffff', 15))

documentation.title: geo_h3cell_rings()
documentation.description:
Calculates the H3 cell Rings.

Read more about H3 Cell.
documentation.returnInfo:
An ordered array of ring arrays where first ring contains the original cell, second ring contains neighboring cells, and so on. If either the H3 Cell or distance is invalid, the query produces a null result.

> [!NOTE]
>
> * For H3 Cell immediate neighbors only, please see geo_h3cell_neighbors().
> * A cell might be not present in the ring if pentagonal distortion was encountered.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *h3cell* | `string` |  *True* | An H3 Cell token value as it was calculated by geo_point_to_h3cell().|
| *distance* | `int` |  *True* | Defines the maximum ring distance from given cell. Valid distance is in range [0, 142].|
documentation.example:
print rings = geo_h3cell_rings('861f8894fffffff', 2)

print neighbors = geo_h3cell_rings('861f8894fffffff', 1)[1]

print rings = geo_h3cell_rings('861f8894fffffff', 1)
| mv-apply rings on 
(
  summarize cells = make_list(rings)
)

print rings = geo_h3cell_rings('861f8894fffffff', 1)
| mv-apply rings on 
(
  summarize make_list(rings)
)
| mv-expand list_rings to typeof(string)
| project polygon = geo_h3cell_to_polygon(list_rings)
| summarize polygon_lst = make_list(polygon)
| project geojson = bag_pack(
    "type", "Feature",
    "geometry", bag_pack("type", "GeometryCollection", "geometries", polygon_lst),
    "properties", bag_pack("name", "H3 polygons collection"))

print is_null = isnull(geo_h3cell_rings('abc', 3))

print is_null = isnull(geo_h3cell_rings('861f8894fffffff', 150))

documentation.title: geo_h3cell_to_central_point()
documentation.description:
Calculates the geospatial coordinates that represent the center of an H3 Cell.

Read more about H3 Cell.
documentation.returnInfo:
The geospatial coordinate values in GeoJSON Format and of a dynamic data type. If the H3 cell token is invalid, the query will produce a null result.

> [!NOTE]
> The GeoJSON format specifies longitude first and latitude second.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *h3cell* | `string` |  *True* | An H3 Cell token value as it was calculated by geo_point_to_h3cell().|
documentation.example:
print h3cell = geo_h3cell_to_central_point("862a1072fffffff")

print longitude = geo_h3cell_to_central_point("862a1072fffffff").coordinates[0]

print h3cell = geo_h3cell_to_central_point("1")

documentation.title: geo_h3cell_to_polygon()
documentation.description:
Calculates the polygon that represents the H3 Cell rectangular area.

Read more about H3 Cell.
documentation.returnInfo:
Polygon in GeoJSON Format and of a dynamic data type. If the H3 Cell is invalid, the query will produce a null result.

> [!NOTE]
> H3 Cell polygon edges are straight lines and aren't geodesics. If an H3 Cell polygon is part of some other calculation, consider densifying it with geo_polygon_densify().
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *h3cell* | `string` |  *True* | An H3 Cell token value as it was calculated by geo_point_to_h3cell().|
documentation.example:
print geo_h3cell_to_polygon("862a1072fffffff")

// H3 cell GeoJSON collection
datatable(lng:real, lat:real)
[
    -73.956683, 40.807907,
    -73.916869, 40.818314,
    -73.989148, 40.743273,
]
| project h3_hash = geo_point_to_h3cell(lng, lat, 6)
| project h3_hash_polygon = geo_h3cell_to_polygon(h3_hash)
| summarize h3_hash_polygon_lst = make_list(h3_hash_polygon)
| project bag_pack(
    "type", "Feature",
    "geometry", bag_pack("type", "GeometryCollection", "geometries", h3_hash_polygon_lst),
    "properties", bag_pack("name", "H3 polygons collection"))

print geo_h3cell_to_polygon("@")

documentation.title: geo_info_from_ip_address()
documentation.description: Retrieves geolocation information about IPv4 or IPv6 addresses.
documentation.returnInfo:
A dynamic object containing the information on IP address whereabouts (if the information is available). The object contains the following fields:

|Name| Type | Description|
|:--|:--|:--|
|`country`| `string` |Country name|
|`state`| `string` |State (subdivision) name|
|`city`| `string` |City name|
|`latitude`| `real` |Latitude coordinate|
|`longitude`| `real` |Longitude coordinate|

> [!NOTE]
>
> * IP geolocation is inherently imprecise; locations are often near the center of the population. Any location provided by this function should not be used to identify a particular address or household.
> * This function uses **free** `GeoLite2-City` data created by MaxMind, available from https://www.maxmind.com. Please be aware that the demo version on MaxMind's website utilizes their commercial service, which may provide higher-quality results than those supported by the `geo_info_from_ip_address()` function.
> * The function is also built on the MaxMind DB Reader library provided under ISC license.
documentation.parametersTable:
| Name | Type | Required | Description |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *IpAddress*| `string` |  *True* | IPv4 or IPv6 address to retrieve geolocation information about.|
documentation.example:
print ip_location=geo_info_from_ip_address('20.53.203.50')

print ip_location=geo_info_from_ip_address('2a03:2880:f12c:83:face:b00c::25de')

documentation.title: geo_intersection_2lines()
documentation.description: Calculates the intersection of two lines or multilines.
documentation.returnInfo:
Intersection in GeoJSON Format and of a dynamic data type. If LineString or a MultiLineString are invalid, the query will produce a null result.

> [!NOTE]
>
> * The geospatial coordinates are interpreted as represented by the WGS-84 coordinate reference system.
> * The geodetic datum used to measure distance on Earth is a sphere. Line edges are geodesics on the sphere.
> * If input line edges are straight cartesian lines, consider using geo_line_densify() in order to convert planar edges to geodesics.

**LineString definition and constraints**

dynamic({"type": "LineString","coordinates": [[lng_1,lat_1], [lng_2,lat_2],..., [lng_N,lat_N]]})

dynamic({"type": "MultiLineString","coordinates": [[line_1, line_2,..., line_N]]})

* LineString coordinates array must contain at least two entries.
* Coordinates [longitude, latitude] must be valid where longitude is a real number in the range [-180, +180] and latitude is a real number in the range [-90, +90].
* Edge length must be less than 180 degrees. The shortest edge between the two vertices will be chosen.

> [!TIP]
>
> Use literal LineString or MultiLineString for better performance.
documentation.parametersTable:
|Name|Type|Required|Description|
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| *lineString1* | `dynamic` |  *True* | A line or multiline in the GeoJSON format.|
| *lineString2* | `dynamic` |  *True* | A line or multiline in the GeoJSON format.|

**Polygon definition and constraints**

dynamic({"type": "MultiPolygon","coordinates": [[LinearRingShell, LinearRingHole_1, ..., LinearRingHole_N ],..., [LinearRingShell, LinearRingHole_1, ..., LinearRingHole_M]]})

* LinearRingShell is required and defined as a `counterclockwise` ordered array of coordinates [[lng_1,lat_1],...,[lng_i,lat_i],...,[lng_j,lat_j],...,[lng_1,lat_1]]. There can be only one shell.

* LinearRing vertices must be distinct with at least three coordinates. The first coordinate must be equal to the last. At least four entries are required.
* Coordinates [longitude, latitude] must be valid. Longitude must be a real number in the range [-180, +180] and latitude must be a real number in the range [-90, +90].
* LinearRingShell encloses at most half of the sphere. LinearRing divides the sphere into two regions. The smaller of the two regions will be chosen.
* LinearRing edge length must be less than 180 degrees. The shortest edge between the two vertices will be chosen.
* LinearRings must not cross and must not share edges. LinearRings may share vertices.

documentation.title: geo_intersection_line_with_polygon()
